CUSTOMS TARIFF (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1996
This bill is a technical corollary to the new Customs Tariff Act 1995 which passed the Parlia ment in the 1995 Spring Sittings with bi‐partisan support.

The Customs Tariff Act 1995, which will commence on 1 July 1996, implements over 500 tariff classification changes to the Harmonized Commodity Description and Coding System of the World Customs Organization. The passage of the act last year provided an effective six months lead time before its commencement and was necessary to enable the importing community to make the necessary computer and documentary changes resulting from the new Tariff Act. It has also enabled the checking and revalidation of 120,000 tariff advices on the tariff classification of goods.

The current Customs Tariff Act 1987 will be repealed by Part 3 of the Customs Tariff Act 1995 with effect from 1 July 1996. There are several Commonwealth acts which presently contain references to the Customs Tariff Act 1987 and its provisions. It is necessary to legislatively update all these references with references to the 1995 Tariff Act and its corresponding provisions, to ensure their continued effectiveness (Schedule 1 of this bill refers).

There are also several types of instruments, such as by‐laws and Tariff Concession Orders, which contain references to the provisions of the Customs Tariff Act 1987. These instruments include approximately:
. 22,000 Tariff Concession Orders and Commercial Tariff Concession Orders;
. 800 Tariff Concession Order applications;
. 1,000 Determinations in relation to the Passenger Motor Vehicle Plan; and
. 300 by‐laws.

As these instruments are intended to continue in effect for the purposes of the new Tariff Act, it is necessary in this bill to enact transitional provisions to apply to these instruments. The provisions, in effect, deem references which are contained in the instruments to the 1987 Tariff Act as if they were references to the 1995 Tariff Act. Where the tariff headings have changed, the provisions deem the references to be to those changed headings as set out in a partial concordance (Schedule 2, items 2 to 5 of this bill refer). In the absence of such a provision, all these instruments will lapse on the commencement of the new 1995 Tariff Act on 1 July 1996 because the 1987 Tariff Act to which they refer is repealed with effect from that date.
FINANCIAL IMPACT STATEMENT
The amendments proposed in this bill have no financial impact.
TELECOMMUNICATIONS (CARRIER LICENCE FEES) AMENDMENT BILL 1996

As part of its election commitments, the Government stated that it will adopt a user pays approach to the funding of the Government's contribution to the International Telecommunication Union (ITU). This bill will assist the Government in doing this.

Carrier licence fees are payable on 1 July 1996. The Government is unable to meet its election commitments without this amendment to the Telecommunications (Carrier Licence Fees) Act 1991, because to collect the full telecommunications carriers' share of the ITU contribution would exceed the amount which the act currently provides may be collected from the telecommunications carriers.

The ITU is a United Nations specialised agency which is concerned with international cooperation in the use of telecommunications and of radiofrequency spectrum, including establishment of standards, and in the development of world telecommunications. Three ITU sectors carry out these functions, namely the Telecommunication Standardization, Radiocommunication and Development sectors.
The Government pays an annual financial contribution to the ITU ($5.8 million for the 1996 calendar year) that covers the work of all three sectors.

Given that the major beneficiaries from Australia's involvement in the ITU are the telecommunications carrier and radiocommunication licensees, it is appropriate to recover the full cost of the ITU contribution from those licensees.

The bill will enable this to be done, through allowing an increase in telecommunications carrier licence fees to include full recovery of the telecommunications carriers' share of the Government's contribution to the ITU. The method used to calculate the share will be specified in the Telecommunications (Carrier Licence Fees) Regulations.
The Government will be acting separately to ensure that radiocommunication licensees also meet their full share of the ITU contribution.
Financial Impact

Currently, telecommunications carrier licence fees include a component to cover the ITU contribution of about $1.2 million in 1995‐96 (the amount varies each year according to factors including the level of the Government's contribution, the ITU budget and exchange rate movements). The financial impact of the proposed amendment on carriers will be to increase the annual amount payable in licence fees by about $0.9 million in 1996‐97. The cost will be shared by carriers on the basis of their share of telecommunications traffic. I commend the bill to the Senate.

—Our understanding also is that it to a great extent reflects the current practice in any event; and I think it is appropriate that these certificates are tendered. Whether the word is `tendered' or `received', we are not going to quibble about, but it ought to be consistent for both subsections, whichever way we go. With that particular point, we support the amendment.
