DEBATE.TITLE: EDUCATION AND TRAINING LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 May, on motion by Senator Kemp:

BREAK.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —On the surface, the Education and Training Legislation Amendment Bill is a very simple bill, the explanatory memorandum going to only a few paragraphs. It in essence seeks to repeal the Training Guarantee Act 1990 and the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act 1990, and amend the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 and the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1992. In regard to the latter amendments in particular, the opposition has no difficulty in supporting those propositions, particularly as they go to providing a rectification of an oversight in regard to support for the open learning initiative, which facilitates access and increased flexibility for the provision of quality tertiary education throughout the community, especially in so far as it provides computer access to students. Therefore, we strongly support that proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the State Grants (Primary and Secondary Education) Assistance Act, the bill provides amendments to allow for $20 million in capital funding for non‐government schools—which, of course, was a Labor government initiative as well. Those two propositions were, in essence, Labor government initiatives. The main thrust of this proposal is to repeal the Training Guarantee Act 1990, which was a commitment that the Labor Party made in the election. That, too, will be supported by the opposition.

Our concerns, nonetheless, go to broader issues which relate to the philosophy of these measures. In particular, our concerns go to the philosophy of this government in relation to the training and education agenda. For us, the issue of training and education stood central to the political agenda in government, and that was reflected in expenditure for this department.

This is an issue which is at the very heart of the way in which the government approaches economic and social issues. If we were to look in broader terms at the main forces of economic development, one often talks about the needs and the rights of capital, but it is not so often the case that the needs and rights of labour are given equal treatment. As far as I am concerned, the issue of training and education has to be seen in that context of being of equal importance to the needs and rights of capital.

For those who have nothing else but their labour to sell, the issue of the skill of labour could not be more basic. Upon that rests the capacity of this country to develop to its full potential. This is particularly important not just for the economy at large but for each and every individual in particular. Therefore, the approach that government takes to the skilling of labour goes very much to the heart of the issue of what sort of country we are trying to develop.

As far as the Labor Party is concerned, we are in the business of developing a clever country. That means to the fullest extent possible, every person in the country should be able to enjoy the benefits of a quality education and training system and, to the fullest extent possible, the state—that is, the government of this country—ought to be supporting such an approach.

That is precisely what we did in government. Of course, that has not been followed by this government. It is not the case in terms of the coalition philosophy at large when we look at their activities and programs at a state level. They have done everything possible to undermine and frustrate the work of the national Labor government in terms of the policies pursued in the education and training areas.

That is seen quite clearly in the case of Victoria, my own state. Commonwealth outlays for schools, for instance, which showed a very importance level of commitment, increased by 40 per cent, whereas cuts to state education programs in real terms were about 10 per cent. We saw that pattern right across the board. So while the Commonwealth was increasing its commitment to training and education, the states were reducing their commitment.

In the 13 years during which Labor was in office, we increased funding to schools by 55 per cent in real terms—a huge commitment. In terms of TAFE and the vocational sector, the increase was in the order of 56 per cent in real terms. In terms of the university sector, the increase in funding was something like 69 per cent in real terms. In terms of the number of university places, there has been a 70‐odd per cent increase in provision. So as far as Labor was concerned, the philosophy of a decent, proper and quality education and training system was predicated on the presumption that there should be an integration of programs—that all citizens should have access to proper education and training at a level appropriate for their needs. That could be at university; it could be at school, through formal school programs; or it could be through the vocational education sector.

We saw quite massive increases in school retention rates. We saw quite massive increases in the number of people enjoying the benefits of apprenticeships and we saw massive increases in the number of people participating in tertiary education. At all levels, the increase in expenditure was reflected in increased access and equity for Australian citizens.

If we look at what has been achieved in terms of training programs in particular, when Labor came to office in 1983 there were 34,000 apprenticeships per year. There were no traineeships at all. At that point traineeships had not even been considered. I refer to briefing notes of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone), a copy of which I have here. The department advises the minister that there will be funding provision for 64,000 program places, which includes 34,000 traineeships and 55,000 apprenticeships. As I understand it, the department is saying to the minister there are ways and means by which those programs could be accelerated to improve the capacity and momentum of the training agenda. I am quite happy for that briefing note—a briefing note to the minister from the department entitled `Labour market training assistance for the remainder of 1995‐96'—to be tabled, if the minister has no objection to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I could look at it.

—Certainly. I will come back to that. The whole contrast between the approaches of Liberal and Labor could not be sharper when we look at the reports appearing daily in the press as to what is occurring in the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. I refer specifically to the propositions that the Expenditure Review Committee has put to the department and which the secretary to the department has put to meetings of officers around the country aboconstitution the possibility of indicative cuts of 12 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: According to newspaper reports—for instance, the Australian of 15 May 1996—it has been suggested that the targeted cut for DEETYA should be set at $1.6 billion to $1.8 billion. That translates to a disproportionate contribution by DEETYA towards the government's proposed budget cuts. It would mean a total contribution of 22 per cent of the so‐called $8 billion budget cuts from a department that receives only about 11 per cent of total budget outlays. According to the reports, that will involve cuts of $600 million in the forward estimates of higher education programs and cuts of some $400 million from the labour market programs which include the provisions we are talking about generally today. Such cuts have to be also considered to the additional programs for schools, ANTA and other vocational programs.

So we have, in essence, a sharp contrast between the philosophy and approach taken by Labor while it was in government and that taken now by a government seeking, basically, to bury this very fine record of achievement. That concerns me greatly.

In the second reading speech there is reference to a modern and relevant training system. What that really means is open to anyone's guess. It is one of those nice buzzwords that bureaucrats come up with and which governments seek to trot out from time to time when they are developing rationales for their positions. I am concerned about the possibility that a relevant and modern training system under this government will mean a market driven training system—a system of training dependent upon market forces.

We have seen a substantial change in the attitudes of employers towards training as a result of the training guarantee levy. A survey was undertaken last year—it might have been the year before—of some 6,000 businesses and 17,000 households which showed that, whereas in the past, before the scheme was introduced, less than 60 per cent of employers were providing adequate funding for training, that figure had increased to some 90 per cent as a result of these measures. Prior to the introduction of the scheme, employers with a payroll in excess of $200,000 provided very few structured training programs for their work force. As a result of the introduction and development of this levy that figure rose to some 90 per cent. It was predicated upon the assumption that there was an obligation on employers to meet some of the training costs. That was by way of the introduction of this measure which rose, eventually, to 1.5 per cent of payroll.

Too often in this country the extraordinary proposition is advanced by employers that only the state has responsibility for contribution towards the payment for training. We see that attitude often reflected in the demand that immigration programs be changed according to either the skill shortages or surpluses that occur in this country at any given time. We also see it reflected in the demand that the state provide moneys for apprenticeship and TAFE training generally—that it is not the employer's responsibility to meet any of those commitments. We are now seeing all of those attitudes breaking down. I am concerned whether we will see a change in attitude back the other way as a result of the so‐called free market policies of this government.

Another area of concern that I have is the contrast in the performances of the previous government and this government on trainee wages. In recent times we have seen the government propose that employees not be paid for time when they are not directly engaged in productive work, despite the fact that we already have existing awards that cover these conditions in apprenticeship and trainee wages generally. I am concerned that if that proposal were taken through to its logical conclusion, for example, you could see an 18‐year‐old shop assistant have his or her wages reduced to some $138 a week. As far as I am concerned that would be an inadequate wage and would lead to a substantial drop in the capacity of people to earn a decent living. This whole issue of training ultimately goes to the quality of life that people can enjoy as a result of the training and their capacity to fully participate in society. This parliament ought to be very concerned about trainee wages being reduced to such a level that people cannot enjoy the decent conditions of life.

This government has advanced proposals in other areas demonstrating a trend towards market domination of training proposals. Looking at an issue such as occupational health and safety, there are clearly areas of considerable need yet to be attended to. It is my grave concern that, if there is not sufficient encouragement from government, there will be too great a reliance upon the employer's capacity to pay for training.

According to surveys undertaken by the National Safety Council, in this country some 500 workers a year die as a result of occupational work accidents. As has been demonstrated again and again, that is largely due to a failure to provide adequate training on the job. Some 10 workers a week are dying as a result of a failure to provide adequate training at work. So there is a considerable need for this parliament to maintain vigilance on these issues.

While the opposition supports these proposals, I believe that there are areas of concern that need to be attended to. I am sure this will be an issue that will have to be attended to in the future. You cannot have a situation where market forces alone determine the level of contribution made by employers to the training of workers in this country. You cannot have a situation where the government exempts itself from its obligation to ensure that all people in this country have adequate access to proper training and proper educational facilities.

In my view, we do not have the right to turn our backs on issues such as that of proper training for workers on the job to ensure their adequate health and safety. As it stands, some 655,000 workers are injured every year largely as a result of inadequacy of the training provided for the use of equipment, and safe work practices. There is, of course, a range of broader issues that go to the issue of proper training. But I would have thought the issue of occupational health and safety demonstrates just how important it is for employers to provide adequate training at work, and the government has an obligation to ensure that that occurs.

What do we see at the moment? The government is cutting back moneys to the National Safety Council. We have a problem here costing this economy some $20 billion a year. What does this government do? It cuts $20 million out of the budget of the National Safety Council of Australia—an organisation which is primarily concerned with these matters. We have seen this government repeatedly talk about cuts and the reduction of services.

It is time that this government attended to the issue of the effects such cuts would have on the quality of services provided. In the case of training, this is often not just a matter of improvement to people's lives but, for some workers, a matter of life and death. Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask that this document be tabled.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: CALVERT

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Vanstone, we will grant leave to table what would appear obviously to be leaked documents. If Senator Carr wishes to table leaked documents, I suppose it is fine. We have no objection, but we do make the point that they obviously appear to be leaked documents.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the Education and Training Legislation Amendment Bill 1996. One of the first aspects of this bill before the chamber today is to provide for the abolition of the training guarantee scheme and the training guarantee levy—something that the Democrats have supported. In fact, we put this forward in our 1994 budget proposal but, in doing so, we not only proposed a three-year suspension of the training guarantee levy but advocated a 10 per cent training investment allowance. So we have long recognised that the training guarantee levy has become, indeed, a tax on labour. But we believe that our idea would have provided an incentive, through rebates and other tax incentives, to encourage investment in labour.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the Democrats did support the advent of the training guarantee scheme in 1990, as we saw then, as we do now, a clear need for greater input from business and industry into the training needs of this country. In fact, at the time of the introduction of the training guarantee scheme, we moved a series of amendments designed to devolve the responsibility for the administration of the training guarantee scheme away from the Australian Taxation Office. We have always had a concern about the amount of red tape involved in the TGL, and that has been based on extensive consultations we have had with groups in the community—be they business and industry groups, or academic or union groups.

We have always expressed concern over the somewhat or sometimes dubious accreditation of schemes. Also, we have consistently called attention, in this place and others, to the flouting of approved industry standards and practices when it has taken place. We recognise that there is still a need, an increased need, for training in our workplaces, and we have long supported a greater role for employers in the provision of training. So today I urge the government to ensure that the abolition of the TGL does not occur in a vacuum; that it is replaced by other initiatives and incentives for business and industry to get involved in workplace training. I concur with Senator Kim Carr's comments on that note.

I believe that, at the time of the TGL suspension bill, the former government claimed the act had achieved its purpose. While I would like to think that was the case, I do take some issue with that statement, and I was heartened by Senator Carr's comments regarding the increased expectation among employers that they should invest in training schemes. However, we did note that there were still a number of employers who were paying directly into the ATO the money that they perhaps should have been spending on levies.

I certainly hope that since the introduction of the TGL there has been some kind of an attitudinal shift in this country. I believe it is reflected in the most recent ABS figures which note that changes to training expenditure in industries are now most likely to occur because of technological change and quality assurance.

In the last financial year it seems that technological change had the most impact on employers in the communication and public administration and defence industries, where 81 per cent and 51 per cent of employers respectively reported an increase in training expenditure as a result of this. In the manufacturing and construction industries, quality assurance most often caused employers to increase training expenditure, with that reason being cited in 30 per cent and 20 per cent respectively of these employer cases. However, in the electricity, gas and water industry it was legislation other than the training guarantee legislation that most often caused employers to increase their training commitments.

I certainly hope that there is a greater recognition given by business and industry groups in our community to the fact that they have a responsibility to ensure that quality accredited training is available to their employees. It is also essential that this kind of training be available to all workers—and I should stress, the newer and younger members of the work force. As I stated in here a number of weeks ago in my first speech, I still believe that there is no other group in society which has been more subjected to the cruel and cutting edge of structural and technological change than that of young Australians. But of course it is not just young workers who need constant updating of skills and skill acquisition. I guess that increasing access to education and training in this country is a prerequisite now—not an option, but a prerequisite—for today's work force.

I should add that quality training should not come at the expense of worker benefits, and it should not be considered an optional extra but an obligatory part of the contract between employees and employer, business and industry groups. Nor should we see workers—any workers, but specifically young Australians—penalised for their desire to undertake training and skill acquisition. I really hope that the coalition bear that in mind when considering the industrial relations changes that they have proposed, and also that they stick to their election pledge that no worker shall be worse off under their strategies.

The second part of this bill—I refer to the changes to schools—fulfils a commitment by the previous government to provide an additional $20.7 million to the non‐government schools capital program in 1996‐97. I should add that the Democrats support these proposals. We recognise the ongoing need for government expenditure on non‐government schools. However, we are firmly of the opinion that such expenditure should go to the less well‐off non‐government schools—those that are struggling to meet basic standards in equipment or facilities. We can see no justification at a time when the public school system is crying out for additional resources for us to be directing taxpayers' funds into the well‐off non‐government school sector. After all, it is the public or government school sector which is educating more than 70 per cent of Australian children.

I take this opportunity to remind the coalition of its election promise—another one—to take up the issue of Australia's low OECD ranking on government expenditure for school education. That was going to be taken up at the first COAG meeting after the election. The promise was to `at least maintain' Commonwealth specific purpose payments to schools in line with the forward estimates. I would like to hear from the minister today, as part of this debate, as to whether these commitments still hold.

I ask that question in light of recent comments by the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Kemp) suggesting the possibility of a significant shift in government funding away from the public school sector into the non‐government school sector. In fact, just last week the minister claimed that the favourable impact on public sector savings of the surge in private schooling is justification for `more flexible funding' for non‐government schools.

I am just curious as to what `more flexible funding' really means. Does it mean relaxing the rules so that the well‐off non‐government schools get more public funds? Does it mean increasing funding to the non‐government sector at the expense of the government sector? Does it mean shifting even more of the costs of education from the government onto individual parents and students? I am curious to hear from the minister today in regard to those issues.

I know that the standard answer is that nothing can be revealed until the budget, but I believe the government can at least give a commitment that any increase in funding to the non‐government school sector will not come at the expense of government schools. I think that those parents with children in the state school system—and that is the vast majority of parents, I might add—are entitled to an answer on that particular question.

They are also entitled to know whether such an increase is going towards the wealthier non‐government schools at a time when, as I said, the government school sector is struggling and experiencing real difficulties across the board. I believe that most parents, despite reservations, probably have little argument with the idea of their taxes going towards assisting poorer non‐government schools. Most parents believe children should not be penalised simply because of the decision their parents may have made as to what school they should attend, where it is or what kind of school they should be educated in. I do believe that parents draw the line at their taxes going towards well‐off non‐government schools where the services are already of a high standard, while their children are struggling to attend government schools that are resource strapped. So I ask the minister today if she is able to reassure Australian parents and the Senate that that proposal is not on the government's drawing board.

The last part of this bill corrects an oversight which would have prevented the minister approving expenditure for the open learning initiative. Obviously, the Democrats support that plank. In fact, we note that, when the open learning initiative was established by then Minister Dawkins, he claimed that all Australians would have access to education if they had a television and a letterbox. We know that that is not always the case; that there are many fees and charges associated with the open learning initiative and many of those charges occur up front. Certainly, the Australian Democrats have been involved in an ongoing debate since the inception of that scheme to argue that the minimum course load requirement in order to get a deferred payment option for OLI should be lowered.

We have always argued that the advent of the OLI initiative should be an exciting technological advance, especially for those groups in the community that have previously been disadvantaged or not had access to higher education and further education—be it because of home duties, disability or distance. I urge that we recognise once again in this chamber that fees and charges for education at whatever level are a psychological and financial disincentive to enter and pursue education. I would hate to see that a scheme that offers such access to different groups in the community had barriers such as fees and charges associated with it. I hope that that is something else that the coalition will keep in mind, especially at budget time as they are considering changes and possible cuts to the higher education sector.

They might also want to reflect on their promises not to cut operating grants to the higher education sector or their promises not to increase fees and charges such as HECS for current students. I say that on a day when we are seeing unprecedented academic and general staff strike action around this country—action that is being strongly supported by students, many vice‐chancellors, I believe, and of course the Australian Democrats. I guess that is relevant in the context of today's debate, while we are talking about achieving a higher class, quality, contemporary education and training system. The Democrats know full well that we cannot aim for such a system while we have barriers to achieving and developing skills, especially in a work force that is subject to such massive structural and technological change—so much so that workers do require those skills.

I hope the parliament recognises today the profound changes that have taken place in our work force and the dire need for all workers to have access to skill development and acquisition. I hope that the coalition, when talking about these issues, bears in mind their election promises, especially their promise that no worker will be worse off under a coalition government.

To conclude, it is time we talked about increased commitments—financial and otherwise—to education and training, not a reduction in the amount that we are spending on our schools, on higher education courses, on further education, or on courses such as the open learning initiative. I commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a few remarks with respect to the bill before the chamber, the Education and Training Legislation Amendment Bill 1996. As has been indicated by Senator Carr, the opposition is supporting the proposed amendments. I wish to make some comments regarding the importance of the training guarantee levy when it was first established. And while it is now being repealed it was, at that time, a fundamental initiative of the Labor government to get investment in training in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The history of investment by the private sector in training over many years is lamentable. This country ranked very low by international comparison in terms of a preparedness to invest in training and to recognise that the training of employees is good for business and good for the economy. For too long many businesses in the private sector relied heavily upon state governments, state instrumentalities and the federal government to gain access to a skilled work force. If one thinks back to the 1950s and 1960s, the post-war era, when much of the major infrastructure development in this country occurred in resources industries and in the provision of services, roads and electricity and to the development and expansion of the economy after the war, it was the state governments, particularly the state instrumentalities—obviously funded both through their own resources and through the federal government—that provided the opportunities for employees to become apprentices and gain their skills. One can recall that such bodies as state railways, electricity commissions and the like were the source of much of the skilled labour. Many employees, for instance in the metal industry, in the private sector, in the private business area, gained their apprenticeships in such places as state railways.

As we have seen over time, those instrumentalities or work forces have been cut back substantially through restructuring of industry and, as a consequence, that pool of training, of apprenticeship, has very much disappeared. I can recall in my period of previous employment in the union movement that the Hydro-electric Commission of Tasmania was probably the largest single employer of apprentices in that state. We have seen over time how there was a shift away from a reliance by private industry on gaining its employees from the public sector. With a private sector that was not terribly committed to investment and training, this country had a real problem.

We had massive changes in technology and the expansion of the global economy. Australia was going through a period of the necessary removal of tariffs protecting manufacturing industry and changes in our export base. All of these things meant that unless we had initiatives to get investment in training in this country our future was looking very bleak. I think it is still the case that we do not have a culture in this country in the private sector that considers investment in training as the highest or one of the highest priorities. I would acknowledge that we have made some very substantial gains towards that, I think largely because of the introduction of the training guarantee levy at the time, which was one of those occasions where government had to act to force industry to invest in training, to invest in its own future.

At the time the legislation was introduced in 1990, the then opposition, the now government, was violently opposed to it and many sectors of industry were opposed to it. Now the attitude has changed because of that initiative. Employers had to be dragged screaming and kicking to the table but, once there, recognised that they actually did have a real interest in investing in the training and, in many cases the retraining, of their employees.

BREAK.PARA: We would not have been able to achieve some of the restructuring of industry that has occurred in this country and opportunities for employees to become multi-skilled, to be able to more easily move from one sector of the work force to the other, which is an increasing feature of any modern society, without the impetus of the training guarantee levy and as part of that overall broader approach to improving education, higher education, and access to training in this country. Many employers, I can recall, were violently opposed, firstly, to putting any substantial investment into training and, secondly, to the government, the state or the union movement having any say in this.

When the traineeship system first started a few years back, I, and many other union officials, went around this country trying to get employers in industry to take on trainees under the traineeship system that was available whereby they were able to be subsidised over the course of 12 months for taking on additional employees to undertake training. Slowly we got them there and I am pleased to say that in the rural sector, for example, where once there was an absolute opposition to this sort of a concept where you could actually have structured training for farmworkers, we now have a situation where my old organisation, the Australian Workers Union, and the National Farmers Federation, have a partnership for training rural workers.

I hope the days are gone when rural workers were regarded as jacks‐of‐all‐trades, or jills‐of‐all‐trades, and the masters of none. Just as employees in other industries are able to gain recognition for their skills, whether it be in the metal, mining, hospitality, or clerical industries, or whatever, we are also now looking at farmworkers, in what is still very much the productive heart of our export industry. We are looking at recognising their skills as marketable throughout the rest of the workforce.

PARA.BREAK: I am indebted to Senator Carr for raising the issue of safety, and the importance of training in safety, because the rural sector has one of the worst records for accidents amongst farmers and their workers. There is a very high incidence of injuries and acci dents, both with machinery and also with the use of such things as chemicals and poisonous substances. Through the initiatives of Worksafe Australia and Farmsafe, employees and, indeed, employers, have been able to gain the requisite skills needed to look after their own safety and that of their employees.

BREAK.PARA: All of these sorts of initiatives have come about in recent years and I believe that it is in large measure due to the initiatives of the trade union movement, together with enlightened employers and the federal and some state governments, who have pointed out the importance of competency based training.

However, what does concern us is that, whilst these achievements have been made, we now face a situation where the government, through its savage budgetary cuts and its attack upon a whole range of programs in the employment, education and training areas, can turn back the clock. I do not think that there is ever a time when you seriously look at slashing or even reducing expenditure on education and training. But if ever there were a time that you should refuse to do that, it is now.

This country stands at a very critical point in its history, having taken on the hard task of restructuring industry, of opening up our economy to the rest of the world, and of establishing the opportunities for expansion of trade in Asia. If, on the very eve of the 21st century, we are now going to turn back because of some sort of blind, ideological adherence to the idea of governments backing away from their leadership role in education and training—

TALK.START.PARA: —Fightback.
—Yes, Fightback—I often think that Fightback should have been more aptly named `Throwback'. But if that is what is in store, then I believe we are in serious trouble in the future.

BREAK.PARA: I believe that education, training and health are the most fundamental responsibilities of government in any society. The old saying is that if you have got good health and you can get access to a good education, then things will usually flow pretty well from there on. But if we do not have those things, then many kids in the future are going to be denied the opportunities to participate in this vastly changing technological world.

Whilst quite clearly the opposition is supporting the proposed amendments, we also appeal to you—if you can actually listen to an appeal over there on the other side of the chamber—to rethink your proposals with respect to higher education and the vast range of employment and training programs that exist at the moment.

I close by saying that through Working Nation—something that is continuously attacked by the now government out of some blind, ideological view more than a real analysis of the success of those programs under Working Nation—we have seen there the development of a tripartite approach to training and employment. Governments, employers, and employee organisations have got together in communities with area consultative councils, as well as at industry level through industry training bodies, to promote training and employment.

On the north coast of New South Wales, in the Coffs Harbour area, a rapidly expanding population area of this country, the `Jobs North' program has been a marvellous success. There have been 1,000 new employment placements in six months—achieved in half the time of the target that was set. It was achieved because of the cooperative approach of businesses in that area, the local Commonwealth Employment Service, DEET agencies, the trade union movement and the local government representatives, all getting together and looking at the needs of that area. The industries that needed to be promoted, such as tourism, did some really great work in providing training opportunities and employment opportunities for young people. I would hate to see that sort of initiative disappear, but I am very fearful that those sorts of programs are likely to disappear.

In conclusion, I appeal to the government to rethink its priorities, for the sake of the future of this country and for the sake of the future of the many kids who will want to get jobs in it in the future, and, in particular, to revoke the proposed cuts in education and training that it is going to inflict upon them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill abolishes the training guarantee levy. It also makes changes to the open learning system, fixing an error that was made. The minister can actually approve the money allocated to open learning for 1996, 1997 and 1998. The bill does not actually change the amount; it just makes the payment possible. The bill also gives an additional $20.7 million to the non-government school capital program in 1996, which was a commitment made by the previous government in 1992.

SPEECH.PARA: The Greens do not support the complete scrapping of the training guarantee levy without a replacement mechanism to encourage training by small business and industry. We will not be moving amendments, because we realise this would not have the support of the chamber, and we will not be opposing this bill, because of the funding arrangements for open learning and non-government school capital works dependent on the passage of the bill.

I would like to elaborate on why the Greens do not support the scrapping of the training guarantee levy without a viable alternative to this real policy problem. The policy problem is how to ensure that industry and business are providing adequate structured training for staff. The training guarantee levy system was implemented in 1990 and was suspended in 1994 for two years. It imposed a levy on businesses with payrolls over $226,000 to spend 1.5 per cent of their payroll on structured training for staff.

We admit that the training guarantee levy was not a perfect system. There were problems with rorting and misuse. However, any taxation based system has problems of avoidance and of people making use of loopholes. There were problems associated with inflationary costs for some forms of training, like conferences, especially right near the end of the financial year. There were problems of compliance, with some 500 businesses opting to pay the penalty levy to the Australian Taxation Office instead of spending it on training. This was pretty illogical considering they could have got a tax deduction if they had opted to pay the levy to an educational institution instead.

The financial compliance of this scheme was quite clever, with compliance disguised as a levy which could be revenue neutral if made tax deductible with the benefits going to an educational institution. It is now quite ironic that this scheme will not be renewed when this same government is making the largest cuts to educational institutions in decades.

I do not agree with simple assertions that the training guarantee levy should be abolished because `it's a burden on business' or `business said it would have spent the same amount of money on training anyway'. This is the simple rhetoric of an ideology that says business can be self-regulatory without checks and balances in such matters. Business does have a responsibility to its work force to provide training and should pay for it. The other alternative is that business is saying that the taxpayer should pay for its training.

If we are to be committed to a culture of training, we must tackle this policy problem with improvements to the current training guarantee levy scheme with alternatives to the scheme. What is disturbing is that there is little or no debate about alternatives coming from either of the major parties. There has been little attempt to make the scheme workable, and the lack of effort has almost been to set the scheme up to fail.

There was also no attempt to challenge rorting opportunities by changing the definition of what constituted legitimate training. There was also no attempt to make the scheme more flexible to live up to its criticisms by extending the definition of legitimate training to include, for example, study leave, occupational health and safety and industrial relations. The Australian Democrats in the past have proposed the replacement of the training guarantee levy scheme with tax incentives for training, such as a 10 per cent training investment allowance. The Greens would be concerned, however, that the burden has shifted more to the taxpayer instead of remaining with business.

There is no sincere attempt to measure the effectiveness of the scheme. I have not seen any analysis on the amount of training expenditure during the two years in which this scheme has been suspended. We have a dire need with such policy matters to evaluate the outcomes of such a scheme so we are fully informed in our decision making. I believe this has not occurred with this scheme. This therefore explains the rash approach to do away with the scheme without looking at whether there is a real need for a more appropriate mechanism to take up the scheme's functions.

We are now left with no accountability mechanism to ensure business provides adequate training. There is no less need for training, especially in blue collar work. A National Safety Council study showed that 600 people were dying per year and that 500,000 Australians were injured at work as a result of the failure to provide adequate training in the workplace. This study examined 100 injuries and discovered that 56 per cent of employers did not provide employees with induction training and 70 per cent neglected refresher training.

We know the training guarantee levy scheme has been effective because we had a 95 per cent compliance rate under the scheme. Prior to the scheme's operation in 1989, we had 58 per cent of businesses spending nothing on training while 74 per cent were spending less than one per cent of their payrolls on training. This was despite the government providing $2.5 billion in subsidies to employers, yet employers were not giving anything back on top of employment to employees.

As an aside, I want to see how long it takes before industry comes to the government on particular issues and says, `We've got a real shortage of trained people in this particular sector. Please, can you provide an exemption for immigration for those particular workers with those skills because we don't want to have to pay the premiums to attract people in that industry back from other industries.' Just you wait and see how long that takes. I believe that is beginning to happen already.

I believe that in scrapping this scheme, without giving serious consideration to improving it or replacing it with something more workable, we are throwing the baby out with the bathwater. The government cannot be serious with its training program without such a scheme that renders business accountable for the amount its spends on training. If one were completely cynical, one would say the government does not require such a scheme because it believes that subsidised jobs with a large unpaid training component will make businesses look as though they were training anyway. The Greens believe this approach will mean an increase in the amount of working poor and will result in deskilling and heightened occupational safety concerns, particularly in blue-collar work.

To recap, because there are elements of this bill which are of benefit to the community, we will not be opposing the bill. We very much regret that we are left with this very unsatisfactory arrangement in relation to the training guarantee levy, which now has no replacement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate to support the Education and Training Legislation Amendment Bill 1996. It is quite refreshing to have after three weeks in this parliament an uncontentious bill. We are actually going to get through another piece of legislation, which, I think, is our second piece of legislation in three weeks.
—Wrong about that.

—Our productivity can only go up, Senator Carr, from this point. This legislation does three things and I want to address each of those in turn. First of all it abolishes the training guarantee levy, which was created by the previous government in 1990. The second point relates to the open learning initiative and a technical amendment to finish off funding for that particular program over the next two years. The third point is the provision of an additional $20.7 million of capital grants that have been promised to non-government schools.

SPEECH.PARA: On the first matter, this bill finally buries the discredited and defunct training guarantee levy. This measure was introduced in 1991 by the former Labor government and was suspended by amendment in 1994. There is now, as you have heard round this chamber today, bipartisan support for that approach. The ALP realised finally that this scheme was ineffective. It was best summed up in an article in the Good Weekend, in the Sydney Morning Herald, in 1993. It stated:

This act has spawned an industry in which abseiling down a cliff is called team building; in which cosmetics demonstrations are training for receptionists; in which gym membership is written off as a stress management program and in which the definition of a corporate classroom is a five star resort.
They were some of the rorts that were occurring under this particular scheme in the name of training.

Industry was very much opposed to this very blunt instrument to improve training in our country. A 1992 Australian Taxation Office survey of companies' attitudes to the training guarantee levy and what it was actually doing to the companies revealed the following. Seventy per cent said that the act created more administrative work; 63 per cent said they were spending the same amount of time, or even less time, on training; nine per cent admitted they were undertaking unnecessary training to fulfil the requirements of the act; and only four per cent—only four per cent—had a positive response to the act. It was a very ineffective piece of legislation created by the former Labor government. The training guarantee levy, along with the so-called Working Nation program, failed. What they did show was a commitment, under Labor, to off-the-job training.

This government is committed to on-the-job training. We will set out, as one of our highest priorities, to revamp the apprenticeship system in this country, particularly at a time when we have such high levels of youth unemployment. The apprenticeship system was allowed to run down shamefully by the last Labor government. There were only 50,000 places a year under the ALP's scheme in 1995-96. That is exactly the same figure as 12 years ago.

Under the training guarantee, employers have no recognition for taking on apprentices. Labor had set up a scheme that was supposed to guarantee training but they had forgotten to include apprentices in that scheme. No wonder apprenticeships in this country declined so drastically over the period of the previous government. As I indicated earlier, the training guarantee allowed executives to go off on stress relief to resorts, and that was claimable. The scheme became discredited, DEET did not monitor the scheme properly, and what should pass as real training in this country, in terms of apprenticeships, was not being done. Good riddance to another failed Labor program.

The second matter in the bill gives the minister discretion to approve funding allocated under the Higher Education Funding Amendment Act (No. 2) 1990 to the open learning initiative, and in particular to its centrepiece, the Opening Learning Agency of Australia. This is to correct the minor anomaly to allow money to be spent in the last two years of the program, and then the OLAA is supposed to be self-sufficient.

This was an initiative by the last government in 1992-93 to improve flexibility in higher education. In reality it was at that time—as senators will remember, in the depths of the recession—really part of the government's quick fix solution to long and lengthening unemployment queues. We also had at that time long and lengthening university queues. People were trying to get into a university and could not. When I came into this parliament, 50,000 people were being turned away each year from university gates.

So the last government came up with this open learning initiative. Treasurer Dawkins hailed it in the 1992 budget as `creating a new era in higher education'. It was supposed to do this—and I quote from the budget papers of 1992:
Every person with a TV or a letter box will have the opportunity to access higher education.

What overblown rhetoric that was. The reality is that several years later the Open Learning Agency, which was supposed to be the saviour of the system and allow proper access to higher education, had only 5,000 students. It has been a pimple on the pumpkin of the system. When compared with universities like Deakin, where there are 50,000 external students just in the one area, quite a contrast is created with this particular failed initiative.

BREAK.PARA: The Senate committee which I chaired examined this initiative in 1994 and 1995. It brought down two reports: one on the Open Learning Agency and one on open learning more generally. The committee, as a result of those hearings, did table in the Senate a number of unanimous recommendations on what the future of the OLAA should be. We felt that the whole thing needed to be integrated more into the university system and come under the auspices of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee. The feeling was that, if we had done that, it would then be owned by all the universities and could become a tool for developing open learning right across the whole system.

Unfortunately, because the system was set up on a cheap quick‐fix basis, this was not going to happen. The sums were all wrong. The amount of money the students paid—it was supposed to be self-financing—was $310 per unit. Our best estimate for the cost of running a university course, even in the arts, is from $600 to $800 a unit, and they were only allowing $300 a unit. Worst still, the participating university got only $185 of this off the top and the faculties got only $100 to administer the course.

So how can we have quality in that sort of system? There is not enough money to meet the cost of running the course. There is not enough money for the libraries and there is not enough money for administration. It really worked in only a rough sort of way because the universities that wanted to participate were prepared to cross-subsidise this system, which is hardly fair. We need to integrate open learning with the rest of the universities. Perhaps, in this revamped form, we could use it as a tool to take open learning into other countries and provide those people with access, on a fee-paying basis, to Australian university courses.

The third and final aspect of this bill that I wanted to deal with relates to the amendments to the State Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act, which provides another $20 million for the non-government schools capital works program. This was promised by the last government and this government is honouring that promise. It is very important because of the very long and proud tradition of the private schools in Australia.

When I was young, there used to be great division in society over whether there should be state aid to private schools. When Menzies was Prime Minister in 1963, he ended this sort of sectarian division that existed in Australian society. From that point on, from 1963 on, there was agreement that the Commonwealth government should have a role in providing funding for these schools, particularly capital works funding.

Unfortunately, over the last 13 years under the last government there have been some changes that have put a major brake on the development of new schools in Australia. We had what was called—and I think it is somewhat ironic, given the nature of what it did—the new schools policy. This policy, which allows private schools to be set up, was administered by the last government. We have renamed this so-called new schools policy the `no new schools policy', because the new schools policy stopped new schools from starting up.

It was instructive to hear what the Steiner school people had to say to our committee on employment, education and training. They said that, if the rules under this government for new schools existed 30 years ago when they were established, they would not have even got off the ground. Out there there is a whole range of schools which want to get started and the government has stopped it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous government.
—Thank you for your correction, Senator. The previous government did stop this because it did not want these sectors which were competing with public schools taking too many places.

BREAK.PARA: It is a time-honoured tradition in Australia that we have choice and that we have choice in the school system. Parents want to be involved in these schools. When I was chair of a private school about five years ago, every time we wanted to expand, a major brake was put on the expansion. They claimed that we all could not find enough pupils in the local area. We kept telling them that people came from all over the region to this private school. They would never hear that argument.

I am very pleased to support the announcement made by Dr Kemp last week that we are going to change all that. If people want to start private schools and they can meet the state requirements, the federal government is not going to stop that sort of choice. We will be supporting it in the term of this government and in the years to come. In relation to this bill, we are quite happy to support this undertaking to put this funding of another $20 million into the private education system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., we will deal with consideration of non‐controversial legislation.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 May, on motion by Senator Kemp:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I expected Senator Short to be here for this matter; but I will speak only very briefly. The opposition supports the Loan Bill. Over a financial year the consolidated revenue fund, commonly known as the CRF, cannot be in deficit—that is, the expenditure over a year must not exceed the moneys available in the fund.

SPEECH.PARA: For the information of the Senate, the consolidated revenue fund is named in the constitution. Where there is projected to be a shortfall in the CRF, governments have adopted the practice of supplementing the CRF with moneys in the loan fund and balancing the loan fund by borrowing. In addition, and I think quite peculiarly, defence funding can be made directly from the loan fund to reduce the payments necessary from the CRF. I am not sure why that is so. It may have something to do with some sorts of financial arrangements adopted during wartime.

This bill proposes to authorise borrowings to be undertaken and to authorise payments from the loan fund, firstly, to support the CRF if necessary, secondly, to use the borrowings to pay for defence expenditure and, thirdly, to pay for the costs of undertaking the borrowings. This is a routine machinery provision that will finance the 1996-97 budget measures. Such a bill is passed annually, except where it is unnecessary due to a surplus being achieved in the CRF.

Given that the CRF is usually in deficit, it is arguably archaic to require an annual act authorising the financing of such a deficit. The parliament's time could be saved by the passage of legislation which grants standing authority to borrow and to supplement the CRF. I will talk with Senator Short about that at an appropriate time. It is important that we have modern mechanisms in place to save the parliament's time with respect to what are fairly standard machinery matters. The opposition supports the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very pleasing to see the support of Senator Sherry for this very important bill, the Loan Bill. It is very pleasing to see that matters of Commonwealth finances are being dealt with as non-contentious legislation. Obviously what we are seeking to do here is to make sure that we can reform the finances as quickly as possible and to ensure that, as Senator Sherry has said, Commonwealth finances are run on a modern basis.

SPEECH.PARA: But we are concerned also to ensure that the level of Commonwealth government indebtedness is reduced. This is why the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) indicated yesterday that they did not consider it appropriate to take the view that we could relax our fiscal strictness in terms of the budget just because there had been one-quarter of positive growth. We take the view that it is not the result for this year which is important but it is the expected outcome for the next two years which is critical to the way in which the finances of this country will be restructured.

We believe that the country has to be put on a firm and solid economic footing, and that is why we are committed to ensure that we do not run a budgetary deficit. That is, therefore, why it is so important we have some sort of fiscal rectitude and why we do not intend to relax our position. If we relax our position, it will only get the nation further into debt. With those comments, I thank honourable senators for their contributions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: SYDNEY 2000 GAMES (INDICIA AND IMAGES) PROTECTION BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 May, on motion by Senator Kemp:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the opposition, I rise to indicate that we will be supporting the Sydney 2000 Games (Indicia and Images) Protection Bill. Again, I am pleased to see the government reintroducing one of our pieces of legislation from last year that had not proceeded through the parliament by the time the election was called. The remarks made by Senator Faulkner on 29 November 1995 on that bill still stand and I want to indicate why we believe this bill will be supported.

SPEECH.PARA: On a personal level, I was a former minister responsible for the operation of the Australian Industrial Property Office, or what most people commonly call the patents office and the trademarks office. This bill came from the powers that the federal government has in dealing with trademarks.

There was considerable debate and discussion during 1995. This legislation was referred to a Senate committee to look at what protection should be provided to the Olympic symbols for the Sydney Olympic Games. There was considerable discussion and negotiation between the Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games, the New South Wales government and us to get a balance in clearly protecting the Olympic symbols that we all know so well, the images and the motifs for the Sydney Olympic Games and the rights for ordinary citizens to use long established symbols in a more generic way.

BREAK.PARA: I think at one stage the Sydney Olympics organising committee probably took a pretty expansive view on who was eligible to use what—associated with the Olympic Games—for ever and a day. We indicated that we thought some of their requests may have been what we would call an ambit claim; but we have negotiated a reasonable outcome.

I think the Senate committee's work on this last year was most helpful in getting a balance of competing interests. Therefore, the opposition indicates its support for this bill. Of course, we hope it adds to the great success of the Sydney Olympic Games and ensures that appropriate income goes to the Sydney Olympics committee in paying for obviously the great expense of conducting the Sydney Olympic Games.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the government, I welcome the opposition's support for the Sydney 2000 Games (Indicia and Images) Protection Bill. I would like to say very briefly in concluding the second reading debate that the opposition's chronology of events leading to this legislation is slightly awry. This whole issue was brought to a head by my motion that this issue be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, chaired very ably by Senator Chris Ellison.

SPEECH.PARA: The previous government had refused repeated attempts by the New South Wales government—then under the excellent premiership of John Fahey—SOCOG and the AOC to have such legislation giving property rights not only in relation to the symbols and motives of the Olympics but specifically for the words `Sydney 2000 Olympics' and a range of others associated with the organisation of the games. The coalition in opposition believed that, unless there was a serious public debate about this issue, the government would not act on this, as it had refused to do so for some two years since Sydney, New South Wales and Australia were successful in gaining the games.

BREAK.PARA: So it was through an initiative of the opposition that this matter was referred to the Senate legal and constitutional committee. That committee did very good work, as Senator Schacht referred to. It brought all the issues into the public arena. Senator Vanstone, who is in the chamber, was a member of that committee. That committee made a unanimous report supporting what was at that stage the position of the coalition in opposition in relation to this piece of legislation.

We encouraged the government month after month to bring forward this legislation. As we all know, as the games become closer, the opportunities for ambush marketing—that is, people associating themselves with the games whilst not having a licence to do so—become more of a problem and more of a drain on the cash flow to the organising committee. We made it publicly known that we thought the former government was tardy in bringing forward this legislation on the second last day of last year's sittings. I only seek to put that chronology in order. We do welcome the support of the opposition. Since that Senate legal and constitutional committee brought down its report, there has been almost entire bipartisanship, as shown by the fact that the bill is listed today as being non-controversial.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to move an amendment, but I have to make one further point in view of what Senator Campbell said in his summing up of the second reading debate. The issues that the then government was concerned about were that, if we had accepted the views of the Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games, people with legitimate commercial rights in Australia who have used associated Olympic symbols et cetera could have been adversely affected within this country.

SPEECH.PARA: We wanted to ensure that the legitimate rights to get value from the Sydney Olympic Games were maintained without affecting the people I have mentioned. I know many commercial firms have been using the term `Olympic' in their business name for decades—and quite legitimately so without objection. They were afraid that for the period of the Sydney Olympic Games they might have to pay a royalty or whatever. We wanted to make sure there was a proper balance. I acknowledge the committee did help with this. We got the right balance between those legitimate long-term commercial interests and the overall interests of the Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Campbell) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN SPORTS DRUG AGENCY AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 May, on motion by Senator Kemp:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, the opposition will be supporting this bill. As I said a short while ago in relation to the Sydney 2000 Games (Indicia and Images) Protection Bill, the opposition's views are already on the record. I refer honourable senators to the Hansard of 29 November 1995.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opposition's support for the Australian Sports Drug Agency Amendment Bill. It is an important measure, as the second reading debate contributions reflect. It is very important that Australia's leadership in the fight against drugs in sport is maintained.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, there has been very much a bipartisan approach to the issue of drugs in sport since the ground-breaking inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts called `Drugs in Sport'. The establishment of ASDA has seen us take a leading role in the world on this issue. This legislation advances the original legislation, brings it up to date and makes it more effective, which will be quite crucial for Australia and indeed all sporting nations in the lead‐up to the Sydney 2000 Games. I wish the bill a speedy passage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 May, on motion by Senator Kemp:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to speak in support of this bill which will provide an additional $95.7 million to improve Aboriginal education opportunities. I am especially pleased because this bill is the result of an initiative of the former federal Labor government. To save the time of the Senate, I seek leave to incorporate the rest of my remarks in Hansard .

—Mr Acting Deputy President, we are grateful for the cooperation of the opposition and other parties in getting this matter dealt with in an uncontroversial fashion, but I am not aware that it is standard practice to incorporate a speech on the second reading without other parties having the opportunity to have a look at it.
—You don't want me to read it out, do you? The whips will shoot you if you do.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, you might like to give me some advice here. I am certainly not keen to establish a precedent that it is okay to come in and drop a speech on the government with a few minutes notice, but I am equally not keen to delay Senator Schacht or anybody else.
—Do you want to have a look at it?

—Yes; the point is that we would have liked to have had a look at it so that we could give you the opportunity to incorporate it, but it is difficult for me to have a look at it while I am taking the time of the Senate to make my own contribution.
—I know, I appreciate that, but it just turned up my desk one second before I read it out.

— I am aware, Senator Vanstone, that it has occurred in previous times, with not only opposition senators but third party senators being given leave to incorporate speeches in the Hansard . Leave has even, in some cases, been given to incorporate when there was not enough time to complete the speech.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I only recently received a copy. Unfortunately, Senator Bolkus, who was handling the matter for the opposition, had a medical appointment and is unable to be here, and his office provided his speaking notes to Senator Schacht. I just make the point that the opposition has agreed for this bill to be listed as a non‐controversial item in order to allow the government to get the legislation passed. In that spirit of cooperation, I briefly spoke to Senator Vanstone, asking for permission for the speech to be incorporated rather than delay the Senate by having Senator Schacht read it. I appreciate that it was very short notice, but, as I say, I did indicate to her that I do not think there is anything controversial in the speech, and the request was designed to allow the government to proceed with its agenda.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: VANSTONE

TALK.START.PARA: —I have now had an opportunity to have a quick perusal of the speech and I have no objection to it being incorporated. I just want to reiterate the point that my personal view is that it is a very dangerous practice for people to come in and drop a speech. Of course a mate, if told that there is nothing controversial in it, is going to say that there is nothing controversial in it. Then you find later that you have allowed into Hansard something that you would not have allowed someone to say were they standing in this place.

INTERJECT.PARA: Medical appointments, funerals, luncheon appointments—whatever—aside, I fail to see that people not attending in this place should have less scrutiny from their colleagues than those who can make the time to be here. Nonetheless, I have had the opportunity to read the speech and I am quite happy for it to be incorporated.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

I am delighted to speak in support of this bill, which will provide an additional $95.7 million to improve Aboriginal educational opportunities. I am especially pleased because this bill is the result of an initiative of the Federal Labor government.

In setting up the National Review of Education for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples in 1993, the former government was recognising the fact, stated in the 1994‐95 report Social Justice for Indigenous Australians , that `Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people were. . . the poorest, sickest, most unemployed and least educated of all Australians'.

The review was established to examine the operation of the first triennium of the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Education Policy (AEP). The AEP began in 1990 as a national effort between the Commonwealth, the states and territories and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to strategically address the educational needs of indigenous Australians.

The AEP identified 21 goals under four main themes: involvement, access, participation and outcomes, particularly recognising the fundamental importance of the involvement of indigenous people at all stages of decision making.
The original joint policy statement of the AEP in 1989 acknowledged the power of education to improve the quality of life for people from financially impoverished backgrounds:

Numerous reviews, inquiries and consultations conducted in recent years have all demonstrated that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people place a high priority on education. They want for themselves and their children no less by way of educational opportunity than is afforded other Australians. They expect that educational processes should lead them to acquire the knowledge and skills necessary to realise their individual potential, lead satisfying lives, and contribute actively to the community. They look to education as a means of moving out of poverty and welfare dependency, enabling them to earn income through employment or enterprise and to manage the development of their communities.
Five years after the AEP was established was a suitable time to consider the extent to which it had met expectations in terms of the 21 goals.

The review praised the AEP for delivering more funding stability in the form of triennial rather than annual arrangements, for fostering co-operation between governments, federal, territory and state, and between education sectors, and for identifying the need for more culturally appropriate curricula.

Not surprisingly, it also found that the AEP's first three years held some lessons for its future operation. In terms of educational participation and attainment, the review found that improvements, although evident, were inconsistent across sectors and systems.

It found that many parents now have an avenue for becoming directly involved in their children's schooling through the establishment of over 2,500 parent committees under the Aboriginal Student Support and Parent Awareness Program (ASSPA).

It also found that the co-operative national approach of the AEP had encouraged the development of Aboriginal studies and Torres Strait Islander studies as part of the curriculum in an increasing number of educational institutions.
These kinds of improvements were not seen uniformly across the country, however, and addressed to only a limited extent the extreme educational disadvantage facing our indigenous population.
The review made 44 recommendations designed to improve Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people's experience of education.
Sixteen of the recommendations apply specifically to the Commonwealth, while others involve the state and territory governments and non-government education authorities.

The former government responded to the review in September last year, announcing a package of measures which included those incorporated in this bill. The response announced the Labor government's intention to make the Aboriginal Education Strategic Initiatives Program recurrent, and this measure is a key part of the bill we are considering today. It will provide greater stability of funding as well as ensuring that funds remain commensurate with enrolments.
It will also simplify funding arrangements, addressing complaints made to the review about the time spent preparing submissions.

In line with review recommendation 37, the proposal is to provide funds on a per capita basis, and in a way which reflects the differing costs of educational provision across sectors, and in remote and non-remote areas.

I note that the government intends these changes to accompany a more accountable, outcomes-focussed process for the distribution of Commonwealth funds. There is no doubt that we need to continue down the path set by the previous government in placing a high priority on establishing comprehensive and up‐to‐date data bases across all sectors of education and training, so that the performance of the AEP in meeting its objectives can be properly evaluated.

The previous government also obtained agreement from most states to increase their effort in Aboriginal education expenditure in order to access a pool of Commonwealth money in the form of strategic results projects.

The opposition will be most interested in arrangements made with the states as a result of this bill. We would expect the government to ensure that commitments made by the states to increase effort are not permitted to lapse due to any reduction in commitment by the Commonwealth, or any diminution of resolve on the part of the Commonwealth. There is far too much at stake.

In closing, I would like to congratulate the chair of the reference group overseeing the review, Mandawuy Yunupingu, the deputy chair, Romina Fujii, and the other members of the reference group, on the excellent job they did.

I would also like to say that real improvements can be made in indigenous education if all governments work together with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. We have come some of the way; this bill takes us further toward our goal.

SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

SPEECH.PARA: Let me turn to the main issue—the Indigenous Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1996. This is a very important bill to have passed. I want to commence my remarks by thanking the government, the Democrats and everybody else for their cooperation in getting this bill put on on a Thursday—

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition, you mean.
—The opposition; that is right. I thank the government, of course, for our cooperation; but I should thank the former government—the opposition—for its cooperation.

SPEECH.PARA: I think this is a positive change for the funding of Aboriginal education. Funding is primarily now going to be on a per capita basis. That means that you get paid on the basis of the number of indigenous students, and there will be some extra money for Aboriginal education as approved by the Expenditure Review Committee. The poor retention rates, particularly at higher levels of secondary schooling, are a very major factor in the educational disadvantage of indigenous Australians. At year 12, for example, the retention rate is only 33 per cent, compared with 76 per cent for other Australians.

The current funding arrangements under the Aboriginal education strategic initiatives program are based on submissions which obviously fail to provide certainty and continuity. Funding levels have no direct link to outcome and do not reflect levels of enrolments of indigenous students. Now that we are shifting to a per capita basis of funding, it is going to be much more predictable, because it will be based on changes in enrolment demands and there will be this separate money from the per capita money for strategic results projects, which are, of course, going to be time limited and outcomes orientated.

It is worth noting that the bill builds on an agreement, reached at the December 1995 meeting of the Ministerial Council on Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, to set literacy, numeracy and employment targets within the 1997‐99 indigenous agreements with the Commonwealth for AESIP funding. DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (NEWLY ARRIVED RESIDENT'S WAITING PERIODS AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Newman) agreed to:
