TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Alston, Minister for Communications and the Arts. I refer you to the Telstra bonds which are listed on the Australian Stock Exchange with a total value of over $2.6 billion. Can you confirm that there is a requirement under listing rule 3A(1) to provide the exchange with any information which might materially affect the value of those bonds as traded or that might influence an investor to buy or sell them? Can you further explain why no information has been given to the exchange on the proposal discussed by both you and the Prime Minister to set up Telstra in another company?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —It is probably no great surprise to Senator Wheelwright that I am not particularly familiar with the licensing requirements of 3A(1), or whatever else it might be. I will certainly seek advice on that. I am not aware of anyone having brought any particular concerns to my attention. I am sure you understand that at this stage of the game the ultimate way in which Telstra is privatised is very much a matter within the hands of this parliament.

ANSWER.PARA: Those who subscribe to Telstra bonds would have well understood the various permutations and combinations that could flow down the track. Undoubtedly they would have understood—or they could be selling out right now—our policy which did not limit us to the legislative route, although that was always our preferred option. They would certainly have understood, and I would be very confident that they would take the view, that having a significant slice of private investment in Telstra would make a very significant positive difference to the value of the company. In no way would their investment in bonds be jeopardised.

As the senator well knows those bonds are underwritten by Telstra—if not the federal government—and on my understanding, although I will take further advice on this, unless the value of Telstra actually fell below the value of the bond, the value of their investment could not depreciate. They would always get the guaranteed interest payable and would be able to redeem their bonds when they fell due. The only time there would be a risk would be if the value of the company fell below the value of the bonds on issue.

I do not think Senator Wheelwright is suggesting that on any stretch of the imagination Telstra could be worth less than $2 billion. I would have thought that all investors out there would be looking forward very much to a privatised Telstra. They would very much like you to do the right thing and allow it to happen, instead of filibustering in 11 regional centres around Australia and supposedly taking advice or evidence about a matter on which you have all made up your minds. In other words, this is a huge, costly and elaborate charade all of which is designed to reduce the value of Telstra.

The investors out there know that whichever path we go down we will always do it in accordance with the law. At the time of issuing our policy we did not rule out going down the extraparliamentary route. The real answer is that it never occurred to you that we might, so you did not call on us to give any assurances prior to the election. We assumed in good faith that you would understand the overwhelming merits of the case and that you would be prepared—after a proper examination by a committee—to actually allow Australia to do what every other country in the western world has done—in other words, substantially increase the value of the dominant telecommunications carrier by allowing the injection of private capital, allowing ordinary Australians to take shares and allowing Telstra employees to get a return on their own labour input as well as having a direct stake in their own company.

For all of those reasons, you will find that potential investors in Telstra—and I presume that does not include Senator Wheelwright—would want to see us proceed down the privatisation path by whatever legal means as quickly as possible. Therefore, it would not seem to me that there would be any concerns on that score. I will take advice on the matter and if I have anything further to add I will bring it back to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I can understand why the minister may be tardy in informing the Senate about what you are up to with Telstra, but do you not think that you have an obligation to all of those mums and dads out there who own this $2.6 billion worth of bonds to tell them in a very timely fashion in full exactly what you are up to? Given the fact that the bonds are trading now, when exactly are you going to inform the exchange?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —You seem to proceed on the basis that the mums and dads ought to be made aware of some bad news. The only bad news that those mums and dads have had in recent weeks is that you lot are not prepared to do what anyone else around the world will tell you needs to be done in this case. This is simply designed to enhance the value of a major Australian asset. Senator Schacht thinks it is the biggest company in Australia. I hope he has learnt that it is not.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that they are very interested in having a direct stake. They would like an investment in the company. They want to be sure that their bonds are secure, and I have no doubt that they are. I did not hear Senator Wheelwright take issue with my assessment that, unless the value of the company was below the value of the bonds, their investment could not possibly be at risk.

BREAK.PARA: To the extent that there is any legal obligation on us to notify whoever is notified in these circumstances—perhaps it is the Australian Stock Exchange—then we will obviously do that. If it is simply a matter of judgment about whether there is likely to be a depreciation in the value of Telstra as a result of our current proposals, then I can assure you we certainly do not take that view. You asked me whether I thought they should be advised and on that basis the answer would be no.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Short as Assistant Treasurer. In view of the stories in today's paper about the national account figures for the March quarter and the assertions that the $8 billion black hole no longer exists, how has that affected the medium‐term budget strategy announced by the Treasurer on 12 March?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator MacGibbon for the question because it allows me once again to highlight the deceit that Labor is trying to wreak on the Australian people for its own shoddy, short‐term political gain. The assertion by Labor and the Democrats that the March quarter national accounts show that there is no $8 billion black hole is simply wrong, wrong, wrong.

ANSWER.PARA: What the March quarter figures show is that the economy is growing soundly. The government welcomed that yesterday on the release of the figures. But it is important to remember not to get too carried away with one quarter's figures, however welcome they may be. The number of factors that contributed to the strong growth of 1.8 per cent in the March quarter are unlikely to be maintained, as was acknowledged yesterday, and allowance has to be made for those when you are forecasting future growth in the economy.

I also point out to the Senate that the trend rate of growth in the GDP in the March quarter was less than the trend growth in the preceding December quarter. In addition, as we pointed out yesterday, government revenue data for the March quarter is consistent with the Treasury budget forecast released by the Treasurer on 12 March. Senator Sherry said in this place yesterday:
The 4.8 per cent growth rate . . . shoots one very big black hole in the black hole assertion we have heard coming from those opposite over the last three or four months.

Let me remind Senator Sherry and those opposite that they were responsible for not just one black hole but a veritable galaxy of black holes. In 1991‐92, the underlying deficit was $11.5 billion; in 1992‐93, it was $17 billion; in 1993‐94 it was $17.1 billion; and, in 1994‐95, it was $13.2 billion. All of those years were characterised by economic growth.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Those opposite who seem to think this is a joke seem to think that one quarter of strong growth means that fiscal responsibility should be thrown out the window. For far too long in this country the living standards of Australians have suffered because of the fiscal vandalism of the previous government. We have been able to achieve some periods of solid and, at times, strong growth but we have always suffered from high deficits in our external accounts and amongst the highest interest rates in the world.

ANSWER.PARA: If we need any further reminder of just how far we have still got to go to get out of the economic woods, one can look no further than the massive $2 billion deficit for the April balance of payments announced today. It provides further stark evidence of Labor's utter failure to ensure a healthy economy and an adequate level of national savings.

The government has put a carefully constructed medium‐ term fiscal strategy in place because we have a major short‐ and medium‐term problem with national savings. That is reflected in our internationally high interest rates and in our current account, which have constrained employment growth. As we know, it went above a million under Labor and is still stuck at 8½ per cent. Those figures have constrained growth, they have pushed up interest rates and unemployment. That is the reason for the strategy that is being adopted now. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. In light of the minister's lucid explanation of that, would he now list the benefits to the Australian community of the fiscal strategy being followed by the Treasurer?

—Labor portrays our goal of achieving an underlying budget surplus as an ideological pursuit. But what could be less ideological than the pursuit of fiscal prudence and fiscal responsibility? What ideology supports Labor's policy of ballooning public debt? Our policies are not ideological; they are commonsense policies. They reflect the well‐known benefits of fiscal responsibility and reducing public debt. The benefits that those policies bring include easing budgetary pressures by cutting the interest payable on a reduced public debt, lifting national savings, increasing the availability of domestic funds for investment and therefore less reliance on overseas borrowings, reduced pressure on interest rates, stimulating investment and economic growth, increased job opportunities and the promotion of higher real incomes. If that is ideology, I am for it. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Time after time—and you have done it again—you loudly assert in this place that an $8 billion budget deficit exists. In light of yesterday's national accounts figures, why won't you now avail yourself of this opportunity and admit you were wrong?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure whether I need to go over the answer I have just given; it rather sounds as though I do. As I said, the wilfully deceitful assertion by Labor that there is no longer an $8 billion black hole is wrong, wrong, wrong. That figure of $8 billion is not a figure that we concocted. It is a figure that was produced two days after the election by the government's official forecasters, which showed that the deficit for 1996‐97 is $7.64 billion. That is the $8 billion black hole. It is not an invention; it is an official forecast.

ANSWER.PARA: The previous Labor government was all too happy to rely on official Treasury forecasts. They were not going to revise them and come clean with the Australian people. Indeed, that is one of the reasons why you lot on the other side lost the election—because you deceived the Australian people. You knew what the true state of the finances of this country were. You refused to come clean, open the books and reveal the $8 billion black hole which you knew about, and which the present Leader of the Opposition, the former Minister for Finance, Mr Beazley, knew full well. As far as your assertion is concerned, Senator Sherry, it is simply wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did Don Argus say?

—As I said in my answer to Senator MacGibbon, those figures are official figures. If you want to quote people, let me point out to you the statements by very responsible economic commentators today. I draw particular attention to Alan Wood in the Australian .
—Ha, ha! What about the other economic commentators? What about Don Argus?

—You do not like Alan Wood, do you, because he is a responsible forecaster. He said that your assertion that there is no black hole and that we can go easy on fiscal policy, back to the old laxity that you had of a $17 billion underlying deficit two years in a row and almost as large figures in the surrounding two years since 1991, accompanied by economic growth, and you believe that that is fiscal responsibility—the Australian people and anyone who follows the finances of this country and is concerned about the future of this country know that you vandalised the finances of this country and you still do not seem to have learnt your lesson.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will you now give a categorical commitment, particularly in light of your continued assertions that, if budget figures demonstrate there is no $8 billion deficit, in other words, if you get it wrong, wrong, wrong, you will resign?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —You fellows—

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Just take a seat for a second or two and we will see whether we can get some silence.

—You fellows and ladies got it so wrong, wrong, wrong during your 13 years in government that you almost got RSI from getting it wrong. The fact is that, as we move towards the budget and in the course of the presentation and preparation of the budget, as is always the case, the figures and forecasts will be reviewed. They always are reviewed and the budget will be prepared in the light of the situation at the time.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that the official forecast for a $8 billion deficit in 1996‐97 is the deficit you seem to refuse to acknowledge exists. That is the deficit that, whether you like it or not, does exist.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Patterson, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. No doubt you have seen the press release issued yesterday by Chris Schacht, the shadow minister for communications and the arts, calling on the government to ensure Optus remains Australian regarding foreign ownership and control. Is the release factually based? What is the government's response to Senator Schacht's calls for guarantees and assurances in relation to foreign ownership and control?

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Ministers cannot be heard over the constant cacophony on the left. Ministers have a right to be heard whether or not you like their answers.
—I know precisely what he is going to say.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I am fascinated to hear Senator Schacht say that he knows precisely what I am going to say, because if he did know that he would not be here today; he would be outside correcting this press release right now.

ANSWER.PARA: He starts off by calling on the coalition to ensure that Optus does not become a foreign controlled company. He ought to know that it cannot because of some changes that were put in place in 1995. Then he goes on, on three occasions, to say he is seeking an assurance that the government will not vary these rules and thereby guarantee maintaining Optus in majority Australian ownership. And twice more he goes on to talk on about ownership.

The fact is that he has no idea of the difference between ownership and control—a pretty fundamental distinction in this whole debate. Ever since the 1991 and 1995 changes made therein, it is certainly possible to have more than 50 per cent foreign ownership—precisely because of your efforts!

Let me just take you back to the history of this matter. Back in 1991 when you were a not so humble backbencher and Mr Beazley was actually the minister for communications, your government announced that the successful bidder for the second telecommunications carrier licence would have to have majority Australian ownership and that the potential bidder would be required to achieve majority Australian ownership within five years.

But, in fact, when Optus won the bid they had a structure that already delivered majority Australian ownership. Mr Beazley, who I take it is still the Leader of the Opposition, granted a licence which did not require the maintenance of a continuation of majority Australian ownership. In other words, a massive oversight—absolutely unforgivable.

To compound that matter, the Treasurer then went ahead and granted FIRB approval on the same basis. In other words, without seeking any similar obligation for ongoing Australian majority ownership. That remained the position for four years. It was possible to have had majority foreign ownership from 1991.

In 1995, when the government discovered this massive flaw in the course of preparations for the Optus float, what did they do? They were not game to come clean and change the rules. So, to create a bit of a smokescreen, they put in place some obligations to require Australian control but not ownership. In fact, they made it worse. They actually introduced a scheme that allowed you to have passive unrelated holdings of five per cent.

So, indeed, ever since 1995 it has been possible to have up to 80 per cent foreign ownership in Optus as long as they acted in concert. That was the problem. You allowed that to happen. You were the ones put in place a regime. And you seek an assurance that we will not vary these rules because you want to maintain Australian ownership. The fact is you put in place the rules that allow Australian ownership to be in a minority.

I can understand Senator Kernot's desperation in the sorts of scare campaigns we have about BT being a potential buyer for Telstra when she knows full well that they could not possibly, under our bill, buy any more than two per cent. As a strategic investor, a foreigner, they would be limited to 1.7 per cent of the total company and they clearly would not have a vote on it.

Senator Schacht's fundamental problem here is that he simply has not done his homework. He does not understand the difference between ownership and control. Why do you talk about ownership and control in different paragraphs of the same release? What were you on about?

You want us to ensure that it does not become a foreign controlled company. It cannot; it cannot because of the rules. You want us to give you an assurance to maintain the status quo in relation to foreign ownership when that very status quo allows for it to happen—all your own work. This is outrageous.

I renew my offer to you: if you want a briefing on these matters, I am prepared to organise it. It will have to be brief because I know that you have a short concentration span. If you want to borrow my copy of Mark Armstrong's Media law in Australia, it is yours any time you want it. But just get it right: I do not have the power to intervene. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Minister, can you advise the Senate how the government's proposal to reduce the Commonwealth's contribution to public housing by $500 million, or a third of the total national housing budget, would impact on the thousands of low income families living in Commonwealth government assisted public housing? Is it not true that, even with the increased cash subsidies proposed, a low income family in the Sydney area, for example, could be forced to pay up to 70 per cent of its income in rent as a result of this proposal? What would be the economic and social consequence of cuts of this magnitude?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I am so glad that the shadow minister asked me that question, because it gives me a chance to tell him something about the facts of life when it comes to housing reform. When this government came into office, we found that the previous government, to give it its due, had already moved some way down this track. We were supportive of reform in the housing area and supportive, therefore, of the measures that the previous government took. Since coming into government, we have pursued the matter further, and the matter will be raised by the Prime Minister with the premiers at COAG in a week or so.

ANSWER.PARA: You are talking about matters which, I understand, have entered the public arena today from the New South Wales Labor minister for housing. I am not in a position to tell you where the negotiations will end because they are genuine negotiations. I will tell you, however—

TALK.START.PARA: —So what was all that mumbling that you have just gone on with?

—If Senator Crowley would like to stop babbling, I will tell the shadow minister that the aim is to achieve greater equity, greater access to affordable housing by the most disadvantaged. At the same time—and, I think, with the same aim as your government had—we want to achieve greater clarity between the roles of the state and the federal governments in the housing area; we want to make sure that we remove all duplication and waste where that does occur; we want to see that outcomes are agreed between the Commonwealth and the state governments for particularly disadvantaged groups who currently perhaps do not get as fair a go as they should under the Commonwealth-state housing agreement as it has operated. They are the goals that those negotiations will be pursuing.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe that in time—and I do not mean over a decade or more, I mean in a relatively short time, and I will not put an exact time date on it—we will achieve greater equity for those low income earners. The people who are in private rental, as you should know, Senator, are the ones who are the poorest. Something like half a million Australians, the poorest half million, are to be found renting privately in the very sorts of high rent areas that you are talking about. My concern—and I would hope that the New South Wales minister would share my concern—is that we do better by those people than is currently the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —By cutting half a billion dollars out!

—We are looking to negotiate the agreement—and you have a problem in the Northern Territory which needs addressing, Senator Collins, relating to indigenous people. After 13 years of Labor rule in Canberra, indigenous housing is a disgrace to this nation. We are committed to working with the states and territories to achieve better in that area as well.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the minister: is it true that officials of your government have put to the states and territories a proposal to cut the Commonwealth's contribution in this area by $500 million or one-third—that is, 33 per cent—of the national housing budget of the Commonwealth government?
—I am not going to discuss and speculate on matters which are between governments.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment. Minister, I refer you to a recent report by a United Nations panel of some 2,500 climate change scientists and experts who stated very clearly that climate change is occurring and will continue at a rate that will lead to `significant loss of life' and `possibly the obliteration of entire cultures' unless urgent steps to reduce emissions are taken. I ask: does your government accept that climate change is occurring, and that Australia has a responsibility to work with other industrialised countries to significantly reduce emissions? Finally, do you agree that, if your government continues the previous government's policy of attempting to block international action to cut greenhouse emissions, this will leave Australia exposed to international actions over which we would have no control?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I think, on the balance of the science, climate change is occurring as a result of human intervention—and I say `on the balance of the science' because it is not beyond dispute. Nevertheless, the paper that is to be presented by the panel to the Geneva conference in July comes to that conclusion, and it has been produced by a very eminent group of scientists—and that, I accept. I accept also that it is a global responsibility and all states, whether they be developed or developing, have a responsibility to contribute to remedial action and, therefore, look to ways in which we can internationally reduce greenhouse emissions.

ANSWER.PARA: I think the third part of the question was: do I fear that Australia may be left out alone and suffer some punitive action as a result of our position? What I can say to that is that I think there are areas of concern for Australia because of the nature of our economy. In many ways our particular economy is unique among those of the developed world, and we must ensure that we find a formula that not only makes an international contribution on our part but also protects our economy.

We have a responsibility to look after the interests of three-quarters of a million Australians who are still out of work. If you are asking me to adopt a position that will significantly reduce Australia's international competitiveness, then I do not think that would be in our national interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his answer. I just ask for further clarification: in what way is our economy so unique that we have a right to go on polluting the environment at a faster rate than any other industrialised country? Do you realise that there is a range of industries that we should be encouraging, particularly in the solar industry area, that could indeed lead the world with new technology? If we do not support them, surely we are missing out on export opportunities, particularly into developing countries and Japan and the United States.

—One way is that I think we are the world's largest coal exporter, or near enough to the largest. If you have a look at today's current account figures, you will recognise that we have a major problem in our external accounts. If you are advocating a course of action that would substantially reduce one of our principal areas of exports, I would say to you that it is not in the national interests. If you are—
—So, forget about it all?

—I am not saying forget at all. You went on to ask whether we should be developing alternative methods of energy. I answered that: obviously, yes. We are. I am pleased at the voluntary action that is being taken by a lot of Australian industry not only to reduce emissions but also to develop alternative methods of energy. I believe there is an opportunity for Australia to be an exporter of that technology. It is starting to happen already and there is great potential for it in the future. (Time expired)

—My question is to Senator Herron, Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Is it true that at least one of your ministerial colleagues, during a recent trip to the Northern Territory, made statements about the territory government's desire to have the Commonwealth transfer management control of Kakadu National Park to the territory administration? Are you aware of these statements? Were you consulted by any of your colleagues about this issue? If not, have you been consulted since?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of any statements made by ministerial colleagues in that regard. I think you would have to ask the responsible minister.
—I would like to know whether you could share with this chamber, Minister, whether or not you support or oppose this proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Didn't the senator listen to my answer? I just said I was unaware of the statement made.
—Are you aware of anything?
—It is to transfer the Aboriginal parks, including Uluru, to the Northern Territory government.

—How can I support something that I am unaware of, Senator Collins? Come back at it. Of course I do. That goes without saying. Aboriginal ownership—that is obvious. I am telling you, how can I be aware of what statements have been made? Oh, start again!

—My question is to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron. In the light of the guarantee given by Mr Howard last year that the coalition on coming to government would reintroduce the indigenous land corporation bill, as amended by the Senate, and increase the allocation for the land fund by $3 million annually, when is the government going to reintroduce the bill?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The introduction of the bill, as you know, is not in my hands. The funding is already being committed under the indigenous land corporation act. The cut‐off, as you know, is part of your responsibility; it was introduced by you, Senator. There has been no timetable about its reintroduction. If you wish to give us permission to bring it in, we are happy to consult with you.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chamarrette, Sen Christabel

TALK.START.PARA: —As a supplementary question, I assume that the Prime Minister intended to honour his commitment of 2 March 1995 that:

QUESTION.PARA: Upon the election of a Howard‐Fischer government, whenever that occurs, we will act to amend the Land Fund legislation to bring it into line with what has been passed by the Senate.

Why doesn't the minister have some intimation that its introduction is both planned and imminent? I remind the minister that the cut‐off motion does not apply to bills that were presented in the previous session and are available. It is available right now, as is the allocation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —You well know that the opposition, with the—
—Laborcrats!

—Laborcrats, and the others on that side, have been preventing any legislation getting through. We have been trying to get legislation through. You have been impeding it. We have had the debate about the Telstra bill. We have been held up all on occasions. It is in your hands to allow the legislation to come forward. We have had this stopping of the legislation coming through. We are happy to bring the legislation forward, as we gave a commitment to it. We cannot bring it forward if you are not allowing any legislation to be considered and debated and allowed through the processes of the parliament. It is in your hands: start behaving yourselves and let's get on with the legislation that is going through. We are happy to introduce it.

—My question is to Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Yesterday, Minister, in answer to a question without notice, you said you had had confidential meetings with a number of vice‐chancellors. Without revealing their names, can you tell us how many vice‐chancellors you have met? How many of them have offered savings? Have these savings been offered at the expense of student numbers or research capacity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicated to the Senate yesterday that there are vice‐chancellors who recognise the need to make a contribution to shaping any savings proposal that may be required from higher education. I further indicated, Senator Denman, that where vice‐chancellors chose to make their meetings with me public, I was very happy with that. It was asked of me in a question here yesterday whether I had met with some National Party members and the Vice‐Chancellor and others from Southern Cross University. They were happy for that to be a public meeting and I was happy to indicate it to you.

ANSWER.PARA: I further indicated yesterday that, if vice‐chancellors want to send me a letter and mark it `confidential', if they want to come and put a proposal and say, `You should consider this', but it is not necessarily something that the university would want to put its name behind—whatever they want to say to me in terms of there being a constructive suggestion to put, if they want to say that it should be confidential, then I will keep it that way, absolutely.

So I think that indicates to you, Senator Denman, that you have not the opportunity of getting an answer to your question because I am not going to engage in an exercise which I understand people over here would very much like to happen, and that is of trying to divide the vice‐chancellors by setting one against another. If they choose to come and put a confidential view to me, I will keep it confidential and that, I regret to say, means, Senator Denman, that I am not going to share it with you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I did ask for numbers, not names. Minister, yesterday you also told this meeting that you were meeting with Don Aitken, the Vice‐Chancellor of the University of Canberra. Did he offer any savings?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Denman, if the vice‐chancellor of the university wishes to give you an outline of what he has told me, he is welcome to do so.

—My question is addressed to the minister representing the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, Senator Newman. I refer the minister to the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill introduced into the other place on 22 May 1996. Is the minister aware that the proposed law abolishes women's rights to take equal pay cases to the Industrial Relations Commission? Is the minister aware that because of this the commission will lose its power to redress discrimination in over-award payments? To assist the minister with her answer, I refer her to the statement in the coalition's policy document on women of 19 February entitled `Opportunities and choice for women'. This document and the coalition's industrial relations policy entitled `Better pay for better work' committed the coalition to equal pay for equal work of equal value. Can the minister confirm that this is yet another example of a coalition—(Time expired)
—What was the word you were trying to say?
—Broken promise.
—What about your broken promise?
—Yes, tell us about your broken promise.

—I can hear the noise; I cannot see the broken promise. This is the Jennie George line. I have noticed that Jennie George and some of her friends in the press have been running this line for some days now. I was wondering when the Labor opposition was going to become interested in the matter. What Senator Mackay has perhaps failed to acknowledge in all this is the excellent job which the minister responsible for industrial relations, Mr Reith, did in consulting with women's groups very carefully during the development of this legislation. I know that it is on the public record in a number of places that women's groups have expressed great satisfaction with the courtesy and time and attention that their concerns were given.
—Which groups? Tell us.
—They are in the newspapers. Go read the newspapers; they are in the library.

—Mr President, it is interesting to compare the noise that is coming from the opposite side. I did not hear much noise on behalf of women when the trade union movement in Australia was generally pretty anti-women, pretty lacking in any interest in women.
—You opposed equal pay in government all the way down the line. Our record stands above yours!
—I well remember, Senator, speaking to the Clyde Cameron College to women delegates—
—Order! Senator, address the chair, please.
—You opposed equal pay in government all the way down the line.
—Order! Senator Cook.
—Tell the truth!

—Mr President, will you stop the monkey? When I spoke some years ago as shadow minister on the status of women to women trade unionists at the Clyde Cameron College it was a very clearly and loudly expressed view, louder than this monkey, expressing a view about—
—Order! Senator Newman, that level of language does not help things.

—Well, no. Perhaps he is only a monkey when he is outside here, Mr President. Those women trade unionists expressed great concern at the lack of support that the Australian trade union movement had given to women over many years. For your information, Mr President, the Jennie George then of more lowly status was sitting in the back of the room while those 40 or so women were telling me of their concerns about the trade union movement and issues to do with women.

BREAK.PARA: There will be three situations for Australian women under our reforms. There will be those who are on awards, there will be those on certified agreements and there will be those on Australian workplace agreements. Employees currently on awards and certified agreements will continue to have access to the Industrial Relations Commission for ensuring that rates of pay conform with the principle of equal pay for work of equal value and are non-discriminatory in other respects. Our legislation requires the AIRC to address discrimination by requiring it to take account of the Racial Discrimination Act, the Sex Discrimination Act and the Disability Discrimination Act. In addition, section 93A requires the commission to take into account the ILO family responsibilities convention, in particular those relating to the prevention of discrimination against workers who have family responsibilities or helping workers to reconcile their employment and family responsibilities.

There is a good deal of confusion, obviously, on the other side surrounding the issue of discrimination in over-award payments. In this regard employees will continue to have access to the Human Rights Commission to address their concerns. Moving to the AWAs, Senator, they are valid so long as they provide for certain minima and they do not discriminate against individuals on the grounds of their sex. If an employee feels they are being discriminated against—

TALK.START.PARA: —How will they know!
—Just listen, I will give you the lot. If they feel they are being discriminated against they are entitled to go the employment advocate or to the Human Rights Commission—(Time expired)

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the minister at least commit herself to fighting to maintain her government's election policy of equal pay for equal work of equal value for part-time workers?
—You should know; you're a part-time minister.
—Look at you; you're not even a part-time shadow minister.
—That's right. I'm not getting paid; she is.
—Order! All right, we have had our fun.

—Under our policy, part-time workers will have a much better status than they had under the previous government's policy. It was that government that supported the rigidities the union movement insisted upon for part-time work. It is the work that women with family responsibilities, particularly, want to have. You could not bear to allow the women who wanted part-time work to take on your union mates. Under our legislation, they will have much more flexibility. Their working hours, their working conditions and their pay are protected. They will have greater flexibility than you or your mates in the union ever gave them.

—Before I call Senator Woodley, I remind visitors to the gallery that catcalling or any sort of comments from the gallery, or clapping, is disorderly. If it goes on, I will be forced to remove people from the gallery. I warn you against that, because it impairs the rights of others to view these proceedings in silence.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill. As you know, the mahogany glider is listed as an endangered species under the Endangered Species Protection Act. In fact, it is so endangered that the previous government, after much pressure, instigated an $8 million Sugar Coast rescue package to buy back some coastal lowland habitat in North Queensland. This funding was matched dollar for dollar by the Queensland state government and the package was hailed by cane farmers and conservationists alike as a good response to an urgent issue. Can the minister inform the Senate whether it is correct that your government is going to totally cut or significantly reduce the funding for this package? If funding is not going to be maintained, what action will the government be taking to ensure the survival of this species?
—As I recall, we promised during the election to maintain that program.
—That doesn't mean anything these days.
—Another broken promise.
—We are a government that is of a mind to keep its promises.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I would like the minister to clarify whether that is a yes, that the funding is going to be maintained. I believe it runs out at the end of the week, and I can confirm that Senator Kemp did promise to maintain the funding?
—If it is the program I think the honourable senator is talking about, funding does not run out at the end of the week.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, Senator Newman. Is your understanding the same as mine that Defence owns the runways at Canberra, Townsville and Darwin airports? Given the government's decision to continue the previous government's policy of leasing the runways, what compensation will Defence be paid for the leasing of the runways? Can the minister guarantee that Defence aeroplanes will continue to be exempt from paying landing fees at other airfields around Australia?
—I do not have any information on that for Senator Foreman, but I will get it and bring it back to him as soon as I can.
—Mr President—
—Before I call Senator Troeth, could I just mention that Senator Troeth did not miss the call earlier on. It was Senator Woodley who missed the call and upset things.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Parer. Could the minister please inform the Senate of the mining industry's contribution to the nation's economy and the role it now plays in improving the quality of life for people living in regional Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank Senator Troeth very much for that question.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Parer, could you take your seat until we get a bit of silence?

—That is a very good question from Senator Troeth. The mining industry makes an enormous contribution not only to regional Australia but to the whole Australian community and to urban Australia—something that often does not get through to the people in urban Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: I will just take some of the contributions made by that particular industry. Firstly, we could look at infrastructure. The mining industry provides roads, rail, ports, towns, communications, water, and so on, in a whole range of communities stretching right across Australia—and at no cost to the taxpayers of this country. Often on the tail of that flows a whole lot of other industries, whether they be manufacturing industries associated with mining or tourists in tourism industries themselves.

The mining industry directly employs 86,000 people in Australia, which is 1.1 per cent of the work force, and it generates 6.8 per cent of gross domestic product. From the urban point of view, it is interesting to note that something like 300,000 people are indirectly employed through the mining industry's efforts. Most of these would be in urban areas.

The mining industry now exports some $36 billion worth of exports, which makes it the largest exporter in Australia—35 per cent of total exports and 46 per cent of merchandise exports, a massive contribution. With regard to the mining industry's direct contribution to the Australian economy by way of direct company taxation, it gives about $1.3 billion. That does not include PAYE taxes through the direct or indirect system.

The mining industry makes a contribution to the states in the order of $800 million in royalties, and that does not include the petroleum resource rent tax. It is the only industry, I would have to say, that makes those sorts of contributions to the states. No other industry does that.

Our major export industry is the coal industry, as Senator Hill referred to previously. It exports about $8 billion worth of coal. That is notwithstanding the treacherous action of one Bill Kelty, the secretary of the ACTU, who represents the industrial arm of the Australian Labor Party. He attempted to undermine the exports of that industry in his infamous letter to a major coal buyer earlier this year.
The other thing worth pointing out, and the Senate should note this, is that the Industry Commission, in its report in February 1991—after eight years of Labor government—said:
Current government—
that is, the previous discredited Labor government—

policies toward exploration, mining and minerals processing activities are not `clever'. It is not clever to erect a whole array of impediments to one of the few industries in which Australia enjoys a clear advantage relative to many of our competitors. If we could dismantle just some of the barriers preventing these activities from realizing their full potential, the Commission has estimated that the value of resource sector outputs could be boosted by some $5 billion annually, translating to annual gains of the order of $10 billion on an economy‐wide basis.
It is these impediments which this coalition government intends to address.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Newman. Is the minister aware that the opposition has claimed that she, as the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, has refused to meet with community groups representing women's organisations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have been interested to find that that is what the shadow minister, Carmen Lawrence, has been up to. You would think she would hold her tongue on the matter. She has a problem recognising the difference between fact and fiction, as we all know. In the House of Representatives the other night, she said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . women's organisations have had a great deal of difficulty getting to meet the minister . . . She has refused, as I understand, to meet with most of the groups. They have been told she will meet with them in a round table discussion.
She, of all people! She is the one who was not prepared to meet with organisations of any kind when she had portfolios. Look at Link in 1995. They said:
. . . we have never found a Minister, Liberal or Labor, that is so elusive and uninterested in disability issues as . . . Carmen Lawrence.

Look at other organisations that have hit the newspapers saying that they could never meet with Lawrence. Now compare the two of us. When I was the shadow minister for the status of women, I consulted with women all around this country. I edited a book called Australian women speak . I went all over Australia, so just learn your history.

TALK.START.PARA: —A best-seller.
—Yes, it was a best-seller.
—How many copies did you buy?
—I will send you a complimentary one if you like. Would you like it autographed?
—Yes, thank you.

—Opposition senators might also be interested to know the number of women's groups that I have met with, or my senior adviser has met with, at the federal, state and local level since we came into government. They include: CAPOW, Country Women's Association, Foundation of Australian Agricultural Women, National Council of Women, Women with Disabilities, Women's Electoral Lobby, Council on the Ageing, Australian Council for Volunteering, Dr Margaret Alston of Rural Women, Soroptimists Tasmania, the Jean Hailes Foundation, ttrustt—survivors of torture and trauma, Sandgate Business Women's Association, Council of Remote Area Nurses of Australia, Association of Independent Retirees, National Seniors Association, ACOSS, the Catholic Women's League, the Federal Liberal Women's Committee and the Australian Federation of University Women. And I have received numerous written views from other women's organisations.
—When do you sleep, Jocelyn?

—I do not have time to sleep; I am meeting them all day and all night. There are other women's organisations that I or my office has contacted, and an appointment to meet with me has been arranged. There is also the round table meeting that was referred to by Carmen Lawrence, ANESBWA, the Older Women's Network, the Carers Association of Australia, the Council for the Single Mother and her Child, the New South Wales Working Women's Centre, YWCA and the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation.
—Incorporate it in Hansard .
—No. I want to rub your noses in it. That tells you what Carmen Lawrence's word is worth. Let it be once and for all known: that woman does not know the difference between fact and fiction.
—Can the minister tell the Senate what the government's policy is with respect to discussing and meeting with community groups, particularly women's groups?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad Senator Reid gave me some more time to elaborate on these issues, because I demonstrate by example what the government's policy is. The government's policy is consultation—wide and deep, around Australia, not just peak groups here in Canberra. We want to hear the views of organisations all around this country.

ANSWER.PARA: I have set out to hear those views not just in the status of women area but also in the welfare area. I have gone around Australia, meeting with local welfare groups, the groups who deliver the services to the people who get income support from Social Security. I am busy finding out from them their problems and their social security needs for our joint customers. My consultation process will be long, continuous and in-depth. Already the women's organisations are very appreciative, and so are the welfare ones.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Earlier in question time, you refused to answer a question asked by Senator Denman in relation to even the number of vice-chancellors that you had met with. We have just heard Senator Newman read out a great long list of organisations in relation to her activities. Will you not only tell us the number of vice-chancellors you have met with, but who they were?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not consulted with Senator Newman but I assume that she has the same position on these matters as I do, and that is that if she had consulted confidentially with people she would not just at the whim of the question from either this side, as it was, or that side, break the confidentiality of those discussions.

BREAK.PARA: I did not refuse to answer Senator Denman's question. You were here, Senator Faulkner; you should have heard the answer but, since you apparently did not or did not comprehend it comprehend it, simple as its language was, let me repeat to you what I said to the Senate the other day. It is simply this: I have had a number of discussions with vice‐chancellors and, if vice‐chancellors want to make those discussions public, I am perfectly and completely happy for them to do so. But I will not do so myself. It is as simple as that.

Where the nature of the meeting has become public and, quite clearly, that is going to happen by virtue of the fact that a vice‐chancellor is quite happy for that to happen, then I am not at all disturbed by that. But I repeat: if a vice‐chancellor wants to see me confidentially or write to me and put `confidential' on the top, then those discussions will stay private.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps the minister could explain to the Senate why there is one approach from Senator Newman and one approach from Senator Vanstone.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —You might like to ask Senator Newman, Senator Faulkner, but what I have told you is that, if a discussion is confidential, I will keep it that way. It is an extraordinary proposition that you are putting to me. What you are asking me to say is that, if vice‐chancellors want to write to me confidentially, you have a greater right to know what is in the letter because you are in this place.

ANSWER.PARA: I just repeat for you: I do not think there is any difference between Senator Newman and me. If she has had open and public discussions with people and she is happy to come and tell you about those discussions or tell you whom she has met with, fine. But if I have had letters from people and they have marked them `confidential' or they tell me something in confidence, I will keep it that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, Senator Conroy asked me a question about the Australian Defence Force Academy. I seek leave to incorporate an answer in Hansard .

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
Response to Question Without Notice
Senator Conroy asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, on 29 May 1996:

My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, and I ask could you please explain the nature of the financial relationship between ADFA and the University of New South Wales? Will ADFA funding be reduced at the same rate as other tertiary institutions? Will you guarantee that ADFA resources will not be used to cross‐subsidise the University of New South Wales?
Senator Newman —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

. The financial relationship between ADFA and the University of New South Wales is governed by the 1981 Agreement between the Commonwealth of Australia (acting through the Department of Defence) and University of New South Wales (UNSW).
. This Agreement defines the arrangements under which UNSW provides university education to officer cadets at the University College of the Australian Defence Force Academy.
. It formally establishes, amongst other things, the responsibilities of the Commonwealth for the provision of facilities and funding for UNSW to provide the University College at ADFA.
. This Government has no plans at present to reduce funding to the UNSW for the provision of tertiary education to the officer corps of the Australian Defence Force.
‐ This does not mean that the operation and funding levels of the Academy are immune from the requirement to pursue measures that improve the cost effectiveness of officer education and training.

‐ To this end, Defence is reviewing its strategic requirement for both undergraduate and postgraduate education of the officer corps into the 21st Century, and the resultant roles and functions of the University College.
‐ The 1981 Agreement is expected to be reviewed as a natural consequence of these processes.
‐ This is in keeping with the Government's response to the Joint Parliamentary Committee report "Officer Education: The Military After Next", tabled in both Houses today. (May 30)
. Defence Academy resources will not be used to cross‐subsidise the University of New South Wales.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Short), to a question without notice asked by Senator Sherry today, relating to the economy.

Today in question time I raised the issue of the alleged black hole, which the government now seems quite determined not to mention. We did take a trip through space led by Captain Short of the Enterprise .

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Could Senator Sherry get his processes right and tell us which answer he wants to take note of?
—He did, but for Senator Abetz you might like to just repeat that.

—I will repeat it for Senator Abetz; he obviously was not listening. I did refer in my introductory remarks to the answer to my question from Senator Short with respect to the alleged $8 billion black hole, a term that they do not seem to want to mention any more, particularly following the release of the growth figures yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: Following the release of the 4.8 per cent growth figures over the March quarter 1995 to the March quarter 1996, it was interesting to note what was said today in the radio commentary by Mr Argus—I am sure he is close to many in the Liberal government—of the National Australia Bank. On ABC Radio's AM program, Mr Argus said:
We've just thrown our crystal ball out the window and we've got some work to do in understanding some of the components of the accounts.
He also said that the figures and the strength of the economy could mean that the government may not have to make cuts of $8 billion over the next two years. He said:
If there's this sort of growth in the economy that would be a fair assumption.
So we have none other than Mr Argus—

TALK.START.PARA: —That's Australia's biggest bank.

—Yes, from Australia's biggest bank, an individual who is very close to the Liberal Party, making that statement. We gave Senator Short an opportunity today, after his loud assertions in this place about the alleged $8 billion budget deficit, on the basis of the national account figures yesterday, to admit that he was wrong; that the forecast—and I stress the word forecast—of an $8 billion deficit will not occur.

SPEECH.PARA: We then gave him the opportunity, but he did not retract or retreat, although I note that he used the words: `these matters are open for revision'. I wonder what that means in the double‐speak Star Trek language of the government. I asked Senator Short whether he would resign when the budget figures are released in August if there is not an $8 billion deficit and he is wrong. He is continually asserting that there is an $8 billion deficit so if he firmly believes, even in the face of mounting, new evidence over the last few months, that it is not correct, he should put his job on the line. But all he could say was, `These matters are open for revision.' What matters are open for revision, Senator Short?

He is not listening to this debate. It is interesting that yesterday, in the time for taking note of answers, Senator Short did not speak at all; he got Senator Hill, the Government Leader in the Senate to defend his position—even though he was in the chamber.

This latest figure on the economic growth is yet another figure in a good succession of ABS statistics. We have only to look at our inflation rate—amongst the lowest in the OECD now; we have good economic growth with low inflation; we look at the job growth; we have had four years of economic growth; we look at productivity improvement, research and development and taxation levels. The government is fond of talking about taxation levels: we are the second lowest taxed country in the OECD—I think Turkey is the only one lower. Interestingly, in the expenditure area, we are second last or last in the OECD, depending on your methodology.

BREAK.PARA: So why is the government pursuing this so-called black hole? What we have here is a government determined to implement an ideological agenda—Fightback. It was never withdrawn. It was never dead and buried. It is Fightback all over again and Senator Short is in the embarrassing position in representing the government. Because the government does not have enough money to pay for its election promises, it is embarking upon an ideological cutback of government programs, an ideological cutback of government employment and is also engaged in finding money to pay for its election promises.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Senate is to believe Senator Sherry when he says that this policy of fiscal responsibility to balance Australia's deficit situation and to bring it back into the black is some sort of ideological obsession, then perhaps it might be a good idea.

SPEECH.PARA: That idea is similar to the concept of environmentally sustainable development, the concept of trying to hand on to the next generation an environment that is better than the one we inherited to ensure that it is sustainable. It is equally important for this generation to hand on to the next generation an economy that is sustainable. The absolute worst thing you can do for young people in Australia and for the next generation broadly is to hand on the sort of economic mess that previous government bequeathed to this nation.

I wanted to respond to Senator Sherry's motion to take note of the answer by quoting a few statistics, which he and Senator Cook will choose to ignore. I ask Senator Cook when he gets the call next—if, indeed, he does—to challenge any of these figures. Back in 1992-93, when Mr Keating became Prime Minister, Australia's taxes and charges—the income to the federal government—amounted to $95 billion. At the end of 1995-96 the income was $124 billion—a 30 per cent increase in the taxes and charges on Australia's—

TALK.START.PARA: —The economy grew, you dill.
—Let Senator Cook respond in a minute, Senator Collins. Could we also look at the net debt of the Commonwealth—a very important measure.
—Lies, damn lies and statistics!

—This isn't a statistic; it is a raw figure. So there was a 30 per cent increase. On 30 June 1991, the net debt of the Commonwealth was $32 billion. By now it has risen to $100 billion. You raised an extra 30 per cent in taxes and spent all of it. You increased the debt—
—That is not government debt; that is private sector debt.

—No, this is net Commonwealth debt, Senator Cook—$100 billion. It went up $68 billion while Mr Keating was Prime Minister and while you and that joke of a former minister sitting next to you were in cabinet. These are the figures. You come back in here and correct me if any of them are wrong.

BREAK.PARA: All of the extra $68 billion borrowed by the Commonwealth was also spent. So all the taxes were spent and all the borrowings were spent. What about the assets? In the meantime, while you were sitting around the cabinet table, Senator Cook and Senator Collins—as part of that disgraceful cabinet that put this country into the debt situation that we now find ourselves in—the then government sold $8.7 billion worth of assets. You did not offset that $8.7 billion of asset sales against debt to reduce the debt; you took the proceeds of those sales and paid the butler. You sold the silver to pay the butler. All of that has gone as well.

So you did not repatriate that $8.7 billion—about the range that we will receive when we sell Telstra—against debt to reduce the Commonwealth's interest burden and to reduce the burden on the Australian taxpayers by way of interest; you just spent it. You did not do what we propose to do with the Telstra sale: invest $1.15 billion in another capital asset—that is, the environment—and use the rest of the money to repatriate debt. You took the $8.7 billion and spent the whole lot.

You always spend it before you get it. That is what you have done. You have spent over $30 billion in new taxes. You have spent $68 billion in increased debt. The money from $8.7 billion worth of asset sales is gone too, and the place is still in significant deficit. What you and the Democrats want to say is, `Let us keep those deficits going.'

We have had four years of growth. Most other nations around the world run deficits in times of recession and run surpluses in times of recovery. What did Australia do under Labor? Run deficits in times of recession and deficits in times of recovery. What do you hand to our next generation and what do we say to our young people? You will pay higher taxes, you will pay higher interest, you won't have a chance to go and buy your own home, you won't have a chance to set up your own business because we are paying the highest interest rates in the world. That is the premium that you guys have put on the young people of Australia. Whenever you go to borrow money in this country, you pay a premium over every other country in the land. You stand in disgrace. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, wish to take note of the answers given by Senator Short to the two questions from Senator MacGibbon and Senator Sherry. Since I have been invited to comment by Senator Campbell, can I say that his contribution today, with the greatest respect, is a good example of, when you have got nothing to say, obfuscate. I will be happy to go to the figures any time, Senator Campbell, but I don't want to be deflected from my remarks now, if you do not mind.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday the cover that this government had carefully constructed for itself to justify a Thatcherite assault on services and expenditure by the government to important sectors in Australia was blown and blown irreversibly. It was blown by the statistician, the Australian Bureau of Statistics, when it brought down the national accounts for this nation for the March quarter. We heard from the government that the forecast was that there would be an $8 billion deficit for the budget and, therefore, the most savage cost-cutting spree that any government had ever undertaken in Australia had to be embarked on in order to balance the books. Interestingly, this is from a coalition that has never in its history balanced the books.

But, in rediscovering their Thatcherite roots nonetheless and in their ideological obsession, they said, `This was necessary.' They obtained a degree of credibility in Australia because the source of their forecast—it was never hard economic statistics; it was a forecast, and all forecasts are susceptible to change—was the Australian Treasury.

The only way in which you can assess how the economy is going, broadly, is by going to the national accounts every quarter. The national accounts for the March quarter were the national accounts for the last quarter of the Labor government. Therefore they were the accounts that we, while in government, delivered to this country. They show a growth rate of 4.8 per cent for the Australian economy. That is a very high growth rate. It will ensure that the economy finds work for every school leaver and sops up the level of unemployment. Yesterday Senator Short acknowledged that this was a very good figure. It blows the cover story that there is an $8 billion black hole.

I notice that it was referred to on the AAP wire yesterday as the mythical black hole. Also, I notice that in the Canberra Times today there was the headline `Illusory black hole'. Even the economic commentators and reporters have pricked the balloon of the government's contempt for Australia in its trying to pull a swiftie and pretending that the economy of Australia is in dire straits. It is not. It is growing faster than most of the economies in the Western world and it is healthier and more robust than most of the economies in the Western world. If you were to embark on the cost cutting spree that this government now has set its sights on doing, you would withdraw public sector investment from the economy and bring on a minor recession in Australia which would put more people on the unemployment list.

But what did we get from the government today; any acknowledgment of that? Of course not. We got a story—more of the same; the bad medicine, the harsh medicine, must continue. This flies in the face of what respected forecasting agencies and economic commentators are saying. Let me quote professors John Nevile and Fred Gruen and Mr Fred Argy. In the Australian Financial Review of 20 May, they said:
. . . the figure of $8 billion is itself not a firm figure.
That is what we have been saying. They go on:

It is a Treasury forecast assuming no policy changes and a rate of growth of the economy of 3.25 per cent . . . a small difference in the assumed rate of economic growth can make a large difference in the size of the projected deficit.

The assumption was 3.25 per cent. What did we get? We got 4.8 per cent—a big difference. Therefore, even in your wildest of fantasies that $8 billion black hole does not exist. Education cuts ought not continue. Welfare cuts should not go ahead. Higher education should not be put back. People in the environment should not be disadvantaged by having their programs cut. Business programs that stimulate investment and create jobs in this country should not be cut back. All of those sectors and everyone else affected by your cuts should stand up to this government now and say, `Don't proceed. What you're propounding is a lie. The deficit is not there. There is no need for this type of approach.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —The so-called $8 billion black hole was a calculation by Treasury at a point in time. Under prudent financial management every Australian would expect an improvement in Australia's financial position over time. It is very interesting that this confidence is beginning to return to Australia under the new government. Apparently this is a confidence that the Labor Party is somewhat embarrassed about. The nature of the questioning in recent days does suggest this.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to look at a number of favourable statistics and trends. One degree of confidence that particularly overseas investors have in Australia is perhaps reflected in some of the exchange rate figures. For example, the strengthening in the value of the Australian dollar in relation to the American dollar, indicates a high degree of strengthening and confidence in Australia by people overseas. This is something that has occurred in the period since the coalition came to power. It is not a figure that is three, six or eight months old; it is something that has happened since the coalition came to power.

The tragedy for the Australian taxpayer is that the previous Minister for Finance failed to indicate the full extent of the deficit. In proper fashion, on coming to government, the first thing the coalition had to do was to audit the books to see the true extent of that deficit and to take appropriate corrective measures to bring the future budgets back into balance for fiscal rectitude and to protect inflation from getting out of control. That was an entirely responsible action by this new government.

The new government has a great responsibility in turning around what has been referred to as the chronic deficiency in domestic savings. A major way of doing this is to return the budget from chronic deficit to surplus. This single act will have a tremendous impact in improving the savings level in Australia. For example, the previous government took credit for every ray of sunshine, in terms of income, and then spent the proceeds almost immediately.

A financially correct approach is to accumulate each of these gains progressively until a surplus is achieved. Over time, with prudent financial management, this responsible National-Liberal Party coalition will return the economy to surplus, improve the level of savings and make secure the retirement incomes of all those Australians including those who now have over $240 billion for future superannuation.

The thrust of the questioning unfortunately appears to indicate that every bit of good news in terms of extra income should be spent at the earliest possible opportunity as was the past practice, rather than saved to reduce the deficit. I certainly hope that in the coming months we will see a more responsible attitude taken by members of the Australian Labor Party currently sitting opposite as the $8 billion black hole is diminished and a budget surplus is achieved..

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I was wondering whether Senator Watson was taking note of an actual answer or Senator Cook's speech to take note or whether he was trying to improve upon Senator Short's answer.
—Senator Watson was speaking on the motion moved by Senator Sherry. I call Senator Kernot.
—You will have to go home, Bob.
—I will have to do it on the adjournment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I had to do that yesterday. It is interesting that the government seems to be in some kind of damage control mode today. Why that is so is made very obvious by headlines such as `Growth fills $8b Budget "black hole"', by the heading in the Melbourne Age `Oh, come on Mr Costello' and by the editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald headed `A shrinking black hole'.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ferguson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just like you are, Senator Ferguson, all the time. The point I want to make and have made consistently is that it is dishonest to say this $8 billion is some fixed amount which, for rigid ideological reasons, you cannot move from. Yesterday's figures blew that out of the water. Yesterday's figures showed the economy is in such a state that you now have a choice. That is the problem: you now have to choose whether you will show a little bit of compassion and a little bit of re‐prioritising in your approach to the budget in August. That is now the difficulty for you. Michelle Grattan said in today's Age :

SPEECH.PARA: Peter Costello tried to argue the impossible about yesterday's national accounts. He insisted the higher growth figure didn't make any difference to the size of the $8 billion "black hole".

TALK.START.PARA: —No, Mr Howard.

—Sorry, the Prime Minister; I beg your pardon. Mr Howard, the Prime Minister, argued that it is somehow inappropriate to rely on previous growth when you are building up a black hole but not when black holes are disappearing. That is not fair and it is not true.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with the coalition on this point: some deficit reduction is necessary. We did have unfunded tax cuts. We did have an unfunded Working Nation package. But I tell you what—it sure ain't $8 billion that you have to find.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chamarrette, Sen Christabel

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

QUESTION.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron), to a question without notice asked by Senator Chamarette today, relating to the instruction of Land Fund legislation.

Senator Herron obfuscated and implied quite erroneously that the delay by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in honouring his commitment to the changes to and increase in funds of the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994 was in some way due to the cut-off motion and some degree of obstruction on this side of the chamber.

I remind Senator Herron and Senator Kemp who ought to know better, as should all other government ministers, that this so-called cut-off motion does not stop the government from, first, preparing legislation; second, circulating legislation; and, third, introducing legislation. It stops only introduction and debate in the same session. So far this session the non-government parties have agreed to exempting 27 bills from the cut-off motion and have refused only five. We have not been at all obstructive.

The cut‐off motion would not interfere with the government introducing this bill—a bill to which Senator Herron refused to give a commitment. If a bill has previously been introduced in the other place or in the Senate in a previous session, let alone debated and passed in the Senate in a previous session, as in the case of the bill we are referring to, it may not even be subject to the cut-off motion.

I simply wanted to take note of the minister's answer and express grave concern that the government does not understand the principles underlying the cut-off motion. I regret that the minister does not have a sufficient grasp of that or of his portfolio.
