—You can imagine the dismay, Senator Bell and Senator Stott Despoja, if you had said, `This is the better policy and I advocate that all of you support the coalition with regard to higher education because it will clearly be better for us.' There is enlightenment in that. There are promises in that. To then find there is a hint that this may be quite different means they will be dismayed.

BREAK.PARA: Finally, I wish to refer to confidential meetings. It is appropriate that there be some confidential meetings, especially one to one or in small groups, with any minister at any time. But if a minister of this government or any other government is to give a statement to a whole industry, it is appropriate to take the model that the Prime Minister used last night for the mining industry. There was a special list of a couple of hundred mining executives, and members of the press, ambassadors and members of parliament were present. The basic guidelines leading to the budget were announced by the minister with responsibility for mining and the Prime Minister.

In confidential meetings, there is a danger that the persons hearing from a minister will be captured and will be breaking the confidence if they then discuss it with their own councils and their own universities. I believe there is an appropriateness for a semi‐public level of discussion.

I have a number of things to say. My time is cut short; I had only half an hour to speak in this debate. I can only urge my colleagues in government to fulfil the promises that won us the last election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I am converted. I think Senator Teague has done it. I think just about everybody in the chamber should see the light. The trouble is I do not really know whether Senator Teague was speaking for or against the motion. I think he demonstrated that there were some promises made by the coalition. I do not know what there was in his speech that guaranteed that those promises would be kept. He said something about a backbench revolt or backbench unity, but did not quite get to the stage of being able to report to us that he had convinced the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) that the promises should prevail.

SPEECH.PARA: In the debate I was disappointed that Senator Tierney, who has an interest in these areas, did not stay for Senator Teague's contribution. Senator Tierney has been involved with me and, to some extent, with Senator Carr on a number of inquiries by the Senate standing, references and legislation committees on employment, education and training. In the time that he and I have shared membership of that committee, we have addressed all five of the areas listed in Senator Carr's motion.

For example, the committee has examined the first dot point mentioned, the international reputation of Australian education. As a matter of fact, we had several inquiries covering that area and the value of education as an export industry. Any examination of any of the reports in that area eventually leads to the conclusion that Australia needs to invest money in that particular aspect of education because that is a good investment on which the Australian community obtains excellent returns.

On the second dot point, the university research capacity and course options, I distinctly remember Senator Tierney's keenness to participate in that inquiry. The report and the evidence that we received was clear, that funding in this area could not withstand any sorts of cuts whatsoever and that, if anything, increased funding should be made available.

On the quality of service for Australian students, I distinctly remember the inquiry into open learning in Australian universities, in which Senator Tierney was a keen participant. We were given evidence at those inquiries in particular about the shortage of funds for Australian university libraries and the effect that was having on the quality of service for Australian students.

On the fourth dot point, university teaching staff numbers and morale, I distinctly remember the higher education research funding inquiry where we were given evidence about how teaching and research staff were having pressure applied because of the teaching requirements, the large number of students they were obliged to be responsible for and how the poorly funded and poorly administered research funding arrangements meant that often university teachers were compromised in their ability to properly assess research projects by their teaching needs and the numbers involved.

On the fourth dot point, the potential closure of faculties, suspension of building programs and reduction of student numbers that may result from funding cuts, I recall the recent history of Tasmania's university where some of the variety of options available for students has been reduced. We have had reductions in the variety of curriculum—for example, in the area of textiles, the fine arts faculty; the environment studies opportunities have been reduced; the classics department is no more at the Tasmanian university; and the architecture faculty has been reduced to one campus, the northern campus.

I remind senators that Tasmania is a split campus with some availability on the north‐west coast, the Launceston campus and the Hobart campus. Whenever one option is available at only one of the campuses, it should be remembered not only that Tasmania is a regional university but that the campus is split with so many kilometres separating it. So any cuts which mean that a subject or pursuit is offered in only one faculty bring great disadvantage to Tasmania as a whole. I am disappointed that Senator Tierney was not here to acknowledge that and to see the effect because he and other senators present were enthusiastic participants in inquiries which revealed all of these aspects of Senator Carr's motion. I would have hoped that that enthusiasm could have been carried through to this debate today.

I note that the debate has been enthusiastically enjoined by its 18, apparently, potential speakers. I intended only to speak for five or six minutes but, as it seems there is an attempt to talk this out, I will make my points and I will make them strongly. For that reason, I will not need to curtail my speech.

Senator Teague reminded us of the government's election promises by incorporating them in Hansard. The contribution from Senator Teague begs the question of why National Party senators have seen the need to directly approach their minister. It begs the question of why newly elected members and senators are going directly to the minister. If there was any faith in the fact that the promises would be kept and such funding cuts were not hinted at, then there would be no need for special representations rattling off to see the minister. We would not have the Australian Vice‐Chancellors Committee wanting a direct audience with the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). We would not have the Australian vice‐chancellors leaving this building only a few minutes ago. As a matter of fact, just before I came down here, I burst into a meeting they were having with Senator Stott Despoja.

PARA.BREAK: If there was any faith in maintaining the promises, you would not have such an exten sive lobbying process. In fact, you would not have what Senator Teague described as a community furore and daily headlines railing against these cuts. Of course, if all these people had any faith in the government's election promises, there would be no need for this community furore, daily headlines and intensive lobbying. They would all say, `The government promised it and, therefore, we have no need to worry.' But that is not what happened. The minister hinted at some cuts. You have to ask whether all these people have got the wrong idea or whether the minister has mishandled her portfolio, as Senator Carr's motion proposes.

SPEECH.PARA: I would suggest that if all these people have been led to the wrong conclusion, then it is a great example of gross mishandling. The impression in the community and through all those vehicles that Senator Teague has mentioned is direct and quite clear, that this hint, which was given without a precise number being attached to it—and the minister, through questions in this place, has been at pains to impress upon us that it might be five, 12 or anything else—has been quite explicit, quite strong and quite forcefully delivered. It certainly was not a hint that the government's election promises would be met.

We have had Senator Teague's appeal that careful discussion is needed before the August budget, the suggestion that many on the backbench agree with this and the claim that no decisions have been made. I think we would all be wise to observe that they were made from the backbench. Otherwise, we would have to ask our questions: is this really an elaborate ruse? Are we seeing a `bad‐cop good‐cop' scenario taking place within the one body? Is this an ambit claim? We would have to ask that question because, unless it is, it has all been a waste of time. There has been so much newsprint and airspace wasted that, unless there is some substance and some plan to all this, we would have to ask: how is this portfolio being managed?

PARA.BREAK: I did suggest that I would be short, but I will conclude with this as I believe it is important: I would not suggest for one moment that the Australian Vice‐Chancellors Committee has got it wrong, that the Austral ian Education Union has got it wrong or that all of the participants in the recently convened higher education round table—which my colleague Senator Stott Despoja imaginatively convened and fruitfully conducted—have got it wrong. That group of people, the HERT, included the National Tertiary Education Union, the National Union of Students and the other bodies I mentioned. Because I was not there, I am not able to give a full list, but I am sure that can be provided by Senator Stott Despoja. But I would say that group was comprehensive in its coverage of this particular portfolio.

SPEECH.PARA: To inform the Senate of the 11 points that that round table reached consensus on, I will read them out. They are as follows:
The HERT—
that is, the higher education round table—
1. Agreed that public funding of higher education is in the public good.
2. Called on the Government to articulate their vision for the higher education sector.
3. Called on the Government to recognise the economic benefits as well as fundamental cultural, social and intellectual benefits to the country of higher education.
4. Committed to oppose any decline in per student unit funding and serves notice that we will explore every legislative avenue possible.
5. Demanded that the government honour its promises and ensure that equity and access is maintained in our campuses, particularly regional campuses.
It continues:
7. Noted the international reputation of Australia's Universities and the effects that funding cuts would have on this reputation.

8. Called upon the Government to recognise the need to inform the sector of proposed budgets changes: as the August Budget is an inadequate time period in which to implement the planning required for academic year.
9. Condemned the impact that funding cuts would have on staff and students.

10. Demanded that the Government meet its obligations as paymaster for Universities' general and academic staff and called on the Government to ensure that they are funded appropriately as part of a commitment to ensuring quality teaching and research.
11. The Higher Education Round Table expressed its concern that student housing would be among the first casualties of funding cuts.

If that group of people reached consensus on those points, I think the government should be taking notice of them. That is not just a group of people who have a particular point of view. This round table was able to encompass the full higher education sector and, therefore, its consensus should have a weight which should concern the government—if not that its election promises were not made clear, then certainly that the minister has been unable to convey to the sector exactly what is going on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to take part in this debate because a few of the fundamentals have been forgotten in it. Also, I will deal with some of the terminology employed by Senator Carr in his quite disingenuous motion. It would be fair to say that some of the terminology employed by Senator Carr, talking about the turmoil, et cetera, has been deliberately generated by certain individuals for their own political purposes. Of course, in Tasmania we have had classic examples of that.

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberal Party has a very proud record in relation to education. When we went into the 1993 election campaign, those of us who remember Fightback will recall that even in that dry economic statement the only area of government funding which was to be increased was—what was it? Education. When we were challenged before the last election as to where we would make savings to enable us to fund our election policies, the Department of Education, Employment and Training was quarantined—because that was our commitment to the area of education.

The Australian Labor Party committed an absolute fraud on the Australian people. They left us with a legacy of $8 billion that we have to find. It gives us no joy as a new government to have all our dreams and aspirations for this country absolutely shattered by the fact that people like Senator Crowley and other ministers wasted all the money and went into debt, which requires repayment before we get on with establishing our dreams and aspirations for this great country.

That is the starting point in this debate. We honestly went to the people on the basis of the figures provided to us. It is quite clear that when the Leader of the Opposition, Kim Beazley, was the finance minister, he knew what the black hole was. He refused to tell us; he said it was not available. Why is it that when the new Treasurer, Peter Costello, came on the scene he was able to get the figures within a matter of days? They were always available, but the Labor Party were too scared to let the people of Australia know the rack and ruin that they had brought upon this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can we have some tomorrow? If they are here, if they are available, let's have some now with this new figure—1.8 per cent growth. Why don't we adjust again?

—Senator Crowley, you really are a living example of a failed minister, aren't you? No matter how much the Labor Party squeal on this issue, they know that they bear the guilt and shame of the economic ruin that this country is facing because of their overspending. They sold off our assets for recurrent expenditure. They were prepared to spend $110,000 on a republic campaign which was purely party political. They were willing to spend money on former Senator Michael Tate, on Dr Neal Blewett—and who was the third one?
—Kerry Sibraa.

—Kerry Sibraa, thank you very much. People without any qualifications for the diplomatic corps in the professional area, though undoubtedly suited—I do not make any criticism of that—were being paid more than the highest professionals in the most important diplomatic missions around the world. Why? Because Labor thought that looking after their Labor mates was a lot more important than balancing the budget. Indeed, whilst we are talking about universities, I recall that at one stage the now Leader of the Opposition, the former minister for finance, introduced legislation, supported by the Democrats and Greens, to refund student unions moneys that they lost because students no longer wanted to be members. They took the money from the states.

SPEECH.PARA: I got the figures out of the Parliamentary Library the other day. Some $14.5 million was spent on that. I simply say to the Labor Party, `Wouldn't that have been a lot better taken off the bottom line of the budget?' But no! The student union activists fund the Labor Party and support the Labor Party, so the Labor Party funds the student unions with taxpayers' money. Indeed the University of Tasmania would be delighted and would not even have to face any cuts if they could get that $14.5 million.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even half that much would do.

—Indeed, Senator Calvert. But Labor's commitment is more to student unions than it is to the institutions of the universities. I do not need to give any more examples of the Labor Party's waste, be it on student unions, be it on diplomatic missions or be it on the republican issue—the list absolutely goes on.

SPEECH.PARA: The classic example of the mismanagement of Labor was in the Australian national railways. For how many months did they cover up the fact that they were running at a loss? Minister Sharp came into office, opened it up, had dreams and aspirations for the Australian national railways and thought he could do something with them, but he found they were running at a $160 million loss. So Minister Sharp, now no longer able to implement all of what he had wanted to do, finds his first task is to clean up the mess left to him by the former Labor administration. In every area of Labor administration we look we see the waste of money and the reason for the $8 billion black hole that we are faced with.

The Labor Party then have the audacity to come into this chamber and move a motion condemning the fact that we are looking at cuts. They have acknowledged that they are only proposed cuts. In fact, they are not even that. Everything is in the melting pot at the moment; we are looking at all options. It is a bit like the arsonist who is still at the scene of the crime: everything is going up in flames and he says to the fire brigade, `Don't, don't! You might cause some water damage.' In the meantime you would let the whole building burn down. We are responsible. We will put water on the fire. We will put the fire out. We will restore the economy.

But, unfortunately, just as firemen from time to time have to create some water damage for the ultimate good of putting out the fire, we as a Liberal government are charged with causing a bit of pain on the side for the greater good of putting the economy back in order—something that the Labor Party failed to do and had no concern about. All they were concerned about was getting into power. Former Senator Richardson always said, do `whatever it takes' to try and get back into power. They bankrupted this nation.

It gave me no joy this morning to be on a radio interview, broadcasting to Tasmania. I was discussing the matter with somebody from the academics union. Do you know what he said? He said, `I am not interested in whether or not there is an $8 billion black hole.'

It is a pretty fundamental issue. He could not dispute the fact that there was a black hole, so he just said, `I am not interested in it'. Well, if he is not interested in it, I could throw up my hands too, and with due respect to one of my colleagues who spoke before me, that is basically what he did. `Yes, there is this big hole but, oh, don't take it out of education.' We could throw up our hands and say, `Don't take it out of Aboriginal affairs, don't take it out of health, don't take it out of welfare, don't take it out of defence'.

Do you know, if we were to abide by that we would be taking it out of the future of our children and the next generation. That is the gross irresponsibility of those on the opposite side who are trying to talk to the Australian community and say that there is no real cause for concern about this $8 billion deficit. In fact, what is it? It is very hard to imagine, isn't it, but it is a huge, huge hole.

It is very interesting listening to the Democrats' approach on this. Senator Stott Despoja in her first speech mentioned the importance of intergenerational responsibility as far as the environment is concerned, and I fully agree with that; no arguments. But if you are going to have a consistent approach you also need intergenerational responsibility in relation to the economy and finances. There is no social justice in me and this generation of parliamentarians keeping on running up the bankcard and leaving it for the next generation to pay off. That is not the intergenerational responsibility that the Democrats were talking about on the environment, but for some reason they do not want to apply it to economic factors. The reality is that the economy is very important and from it flows everything else, because without a sound economy, without a sound budget, we will not be able to fund education for the future.

I still recall as a Liberal student being in Western Australia and that great Australian, Sir Charles Court, addressing us. He made a point, it must be 20 years ago or now, but it has stuck with me to this day. He said, `The reason that I place so great an emphasis on economic development for my state is so that I have got a sufficient business and tax base to fund the hospitals, the schools, the universities, the infrastructure, the arts—all those things that people would like to have funded from the public fund'. So that is why we as a government have set about the task of restoring the economy and getting the budget back into balance. Once we have achieved that there will then be a brighter future, not only for higher education but also for a whole lot of other areas.

It would be fair to say that the university community is the most articulate within society, the most capable of lobbying, the most likely to have access to modern technology, access to editors of newspapers et cetera. Therefore, they have been making their point very loud and clear, but not once have I heard them say, `We agree that there needs to be a reigning‐in of the budget deficit'. As soon as they acknowledge that point, and they have to, the next point is: from what area? It is basically the nimby principle—not in my backyard, cut somebody else.

I believe that there are particular institutions in this country that deserve to be looked at individually, and I place the University of Tasmania in that category. I think that there are three outstanding reasons. Firstly, it is the only university in my home state of Tasmania. Secondly, it is a regional university, and for a regional university to be able to survive it does need a degree of infrastructure. But if even my university needs to suffer a certain amount of cuts for the future benefit of all Australians and all Tasmanians, I will reluctantly go along with that because I have a vision for the future of this country.

It is very interesting that the Labor Party and Democrats have been asking us to provide a vision for the future for higher education. I think that is very vital and I think that is a great challenge facing the minister, Senator Vanstone. But I challenge those people also to provide a plan for the future about the budget deficit. How are we going to deal with that for the future? How are my children going to be able to have an Australia which is not that much in debt that they will not be able to do what they want other than pay off the international bankcard that we have run up for them?

There is terminology in this motion which I find offensive. There is talk about the `turmoil engulfing Australia's universities'. Who is generating some of the turmoil? I suppose it depends on your definition of `turmoil'. A street demonstration, no problem with that; articulating, no problem with that. But when you confront the sort of nonsensical activism that my office confronted in recent times, and then you look behind it, you see the young people from the Australian Labor Party. I dealt with that in a previous speech. But when damage is done to buildings and tomatoes brought to the scene and thrown at the building, you have to ask the question: how does this assist the debate in any shape or form? It does not at all but it creates a climate of turmoil and that of course is the plan of the Australian Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did they turn up at your place today? Did the students turn up?

—Senator Calvert asks whether the students turned up at my office today. Of course they didn't. Allow me to indicate what Senator Calvert was referring to. After their pathetic demonstration, which required the attendance of police, the student union leader, Anthony Llewellyn, well-known Labor Party activist in Tasmania, said, `We will return every lunchtime until we meet with Senator Abetz.' I had refused to meet with him until he apologised to my staff member for the harassment that she suffered and until he paid the damages bill of $815.

SPEECH.PARA: Well, Madam Deputy President, I tell you what. On Tuesday only six turned up. This great student leader that talked for the thousands of students at the University of Tasmania could muster all of six. It would not even have been half of the Labor club on campus—not even half of the Labor club turned up. Do you know how long they stayed for? Ten minutes. Then they trotted over to the hotel across the road.

TALK.START.PARA: —The old Telegraph.

—Absolutely, Senator Calvert, the old Telegraph. The next day there was not a single soul outside. The demonstration did not even last for a week. I issued a media release indicating how pathetic this campaign had been, how idle the threat was and how this student union leader was clearly not speaking on behalf of the students at the University of Tasmania. The next threat was, `We've changed tactics; we are going to inundate Senator Abetz's office with phone calls and faxes.' They issued a media release of that nature.

SPEECH.PARA: All the journalists got the media release and thought, `You beauty. Let's see how it is working.' They rang my office, and within two rings the phone was answered. They came to the conclusion that once again the campaign was an absolute, abysmal failure. The sort of turmoil that certain elements within the community are trying to generate is clearly for party political purposes and not for the purpose of assisting the universities in this very difficult time.

I have spent 1½ hours, along with a number of my Tasmanian colleagues, with the Vice-Chancellor of the University of Tasmania. We see the difficulties, and it gives us no joy. I say to the vast number of genuine students who have rung me to make a point—all of them, might I add, disassociating themselves from the student union‐inspired activity—`Can you imagine any politician going to the electorate and saying, "I am going to cut funding"?'

The nature of the political beast is that you usually like to hand out the money—like the former Labor government, which got us into this mess, did. We are saying that rather than simply handing out largess, there is the necessity for responsibility. We are willing, even if it is for short-term political pain, to get the benefit and the recognition for taking the hard and tough decisions that are undoubtedly required.

A lot of people within the small business community, the farmers and the shopkeepers, ask me, `Why is it that over the past decade our incomes have fallen so dramatically, yet those who live off the public sector have not really had to make the sorts of substantial cuts that we have had to endure?' I believe this government has led by example. Junior ministers have had pay cuts. Do you remember the National Media Liaison Service? How many millions of dollars did that cost? It was the propaganda machine of the ALP, funded by the taxpayers. It was abolished by us, saving money. It would have been politically astute for us simply to have kept it, to return the compliments to the ALP. But, no, we are committed to getting this country back on track. That means sometimes taking some hard and difficult decisions.

This motion talks about proposed budget cutbacks. What is the proposal? It also talks about indiscriminate funding cuts. What indiscriminate funding cuts? What is the percentage figure? Which aspects are going to be cut? You don't know.

TALK.START.PARA: —They know all about indiscriminate tax rises; that is their business.

—Yes. The reality is that we on this side do not know either because we are still in the situation of public consultation. Everything will be revealed on 20 August in the budget. I suppose the budget, in rough terms, will be put to bed in early August. There is still another two full months of community consultation that can and will take place.

SPEECH.PARA: I was late to the AMEC dinner last night because I was talking to a genuine student who wanted to find out some facts. The student union had put out a sheet saying that there would be a 12 per cent cut. That is the Labor Party line. They say, `There will be a 12 per cent cut. This 12 per cent cut will have such and such an effect on the University of Tasmania.' I told him that no decision has been made, that everything is still in the melting pot. We are still considering what we have to do because of Labor's mismanagement. Labor's mismanagement is the cause of our considerations.

The first thing any government coming into office would want to do is to fulfil their dreams and aspirations. Instead, we opened the cupboard and found an absolute mess. We are now, in a proper, genuine way, going about overcoming the difficulties.

TALK.START.PARA: —A 4.8 per cent growth rate?

—Senator Mackay asks about the growth rate. It was a great result. Everybody is happy about it. But you know what you did. You ran up the debt whilst we were having negative growth. Whilst we had positive growth, you continued to run up the debt. What you do when you have positive growth is repay your debt—something you people never comprehended.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party needs to realise the basic economic principle that every small business knows. When you have a good month, you use that to pay off the overdraft you incurred during the bad month. But the Labor Party does not do that. If they have a bad month, it will be the overdraft. If they have a good month, they will spend all that and increase the overdraft. There has to be an end, and it will either be the big crash or a sensible reduction. That is what we are setting out to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —They flog a few assets and still keep the overdraft up.

—Exactly, Senator Campbell. It amazes me that the Australian Labor Party has no sense of shame at the way they dealt with our economy. You would have thought that, if there was any ounce of decency within them, they would not wish to engage in any debate that in any way touches upon the economy. They just seem to say, `We're out of government; it's not our fault anymore.' I remember the last question time before the election. The senators who were sitting on this side then—Senator Cook and others—were still blaming Malcolm Fraser and John Howard for the economic ills, when the Liberal Party had not been in government for 13 years.

SPEECH.PARA: Now that Labor Party senators are in opposition, and just out of government for a few weeks, they are straightaway blaming us for the economic ills. It really is a duplicity that the people of Australia can see through. You are exposed and shown for the poor economic performers that you really are.

I believe that a sensible approach needs to be taken to all areas of government, and that is currently what we are embarking upon. There are no specific proposals at this stage. There are no indiscriminate funding cuts and, if there are, you should tell us about them. But of course there are not any. The Labor Party knows there are not any, and they know that we are currently in the consultation stage.

Senator Mackay is trying to interject but, if she had been in parliament a bit longer, she would have realised that we used to play the game on the other side as well. The ministers would be asked just before the budget, `Can you give a guarantee that this won't be cut or that won't be cut?' And Senator Cook would get up, very high and mightily, puff out his little chest and try to use the latest buzz word that he had learnt—he usually could not pronounce it, which was very embarrassing. That aside, he would say, `I will not give you an insight into our budgetary considerations.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Wait till budget night.
—`Wait till budget night,' was his line. `You wait till the budget.'
—Good.

—Senator Mackay is now agreeing that that is appropriate. That is exactly what I am saying to Senator Mackay and the Australian Labor Party: do not engage in this deliberate scare campaign. By all means, you should put the case of the university as strongly as you can and assist with the lobbying wherever you can. You can do those sorts of things.

SPEECH.PARA: But Senator Mackay would understand that that sort of lobbying is not assisted by producing a crate of tomatoes and damaging public offices to the extent of $815, as was inspired by Labor students at the University of Tasmania. That does nothing for the cause, but a peaceful rally outside our state Parliament House with 2,000 in attendance is clearly a proper, peaceful way to make your point.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about a debate at the university?

—Senator Mackay asked, `What about a debate at the university?' I think Senator Mackay wants to go back to the dreamtime. A few people around here might not be aware of this, but Senator Mackay and I were at university together. We used to have debates but, come the student election results, who used to top the poll, Senator Mackay? Who used to lead the AUS delegation each year? And I am more than happy to go back and give you another dose. I would have thought that, after a gap of about 15 years, you would have learnt your lesson and would not want to go back into that sort of forum.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Mackay, I am willing to debate you anywhere that is suitable to me, but—and this is the caveat—it will not be sponsored by the irresponsible University of Tasmania union until such time as they have paid for the damage to the building in which I have got my office and have had the decency to apologise to my staff member.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank goodness that is finished. In Senator Abetz, we saw a person who managed to address not at all the breaking of promises in education, while he trawled across just about everything else that might be a distraction. Before you leave, Senator Abetz, there are a number of things I want to say. It was not the Labor party that started the hares running in this debate. It was the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone. Nobody else but the minister. That is the first point. The minister started it herself.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Abetz can say what he likes, but this debate has nothing to do with the Labor Party, the vice-chancellors, the staff or the students. The furore, the chaos, the confusion, the anxiety and the panic were started by the minister. She has told us on a number of occasions that the number might have been five or 12 per cent—whatever figure she dropped in the friendly debate. That is why we are raising this: the minister started this.

Senator Abetz is departing this place having made his contribution. He said that the coalition is the responsible government and that they are now going to cut expenditure. Let me remind you of what you did in my area late last year just before the election. You actually voted—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: I have been very impressed with the way you have kept control of the chamber throughout your time in the chair. However, I note that Senator Crowley has referred to Senator Abetz directly across the chamber on a number of occasions in the last couple of minutes. Under standing orders, she is required to direct her remarks through the chair.

—Thank you, Senator Campbell. There is a point of order, but I would also remind Senator Abetz that he is not actually sitting in his own seat. Two wrongs do not make a right. I would ask him to return to his seat, and I would tell Senator Crowley that it would be helpful if she directed her remarks through the chair.

—I take your instruction on this, and I would also ask what on earth Senator Campbell is afraid of that he has to be up on his feet and cutting down my time when I have only been going for a minute. He does not like it, and he does not like the fact that one of the things that he and his colleagues did when they were on this side of the chamber was to come in here and vote against a savings measure of $140 million that we proposed in the child‐care area. I am glad to note that the aforementioned Senator Abetz does not put that on his waste watch list. He is a disgraceful little thing. You want to talk about balance and you want to talk about a proper budget—
—Order! Senator Crowley, to call someone a `disgraceful little thing' is unparliamentary. I ask you to withdraw it.

—I am sorry. His thinking is disgraceful. Thank you very much, Madam Acting Deputy President; I am advised by you again. What is the issue? I am not going to get distracted too much by Senator Abetz, because that is a big distraction. He had to come in here and float that red herring around because he did not want in any way to address the motion, and he particularly did not like to follow Senator Teague, who is making the motions very well for us: very good support!

BREAK.PARA: There were a couple of points that Senator Teague had to point out. I am sure that the Labor opposition will be interested to read his quote exactly. But, as I can generally recall it and represent it, Senator Teague pointed out that the recent quarter's figures of growth show that there is the potential for an adjustment in the figures for what the government now might have to find. In other words, Senator Teague, who made a remarkably honest speech for his contribution, actually pointed out that those growth figures quite clearly mean that the $8 billion dollar black hole—which was not there before—is very certainly gone for all time now.

I noted that the government when in opposition said during the election campaign that we could have those figures very quickly. I would like in passing to challenge them to let us have them in the next day or two—and adjusted for those changed figures for growth. Most people around the place put the difference at about $2 billion or $2½ billion: an over one per cent difference in your estimates for growth. I do not think we should push that line too hard because, if we did get the figures—and we know we will not, because you are not about to give them—you would see that there is a lot of merit and justice in what Senator Teague had to say. Going back to the issue, this motion asks us—

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't know what he was saying. I couldn't understand it at all.

—Just you wait your turn, Senator—through you, Madam Chair—you will get your turn in no time at all. The first part of this motion concerns itself with the turmoil engulfing Australian universities as a result of the coalition government's proposed budget cuts. I say for the record once again that it is not a plot of the Labor Party, students or anybody else to stir the possum here. This has been done by Minister Vanstone herself, all alone and unassisted, with an absolute display of incompetence and insufficiency that is unmatched, I believe, in terms of starting the hares running, having no policy and there being a complete vacuum in which you might even be considering these cuts. You do nothing except say, `Well, everyone's got to share in the cuts.' Why?

BREAK.PARA: Why is it, if that be the case, that the Defence budget—we are told—will not have to share in the cuts? Why, if you are looking to the future of this country, would you put a wall around guns but cut the butter? Why would you want to choose that? I do not know the thinking in the government party on this, or why their minds would prefer to protect defence and cut education, but it certainly does seem to be a curious position to hold, particularly when we have heard in here the passionate pleading from the other side on the importance of education.

If you are serious, fix it. Fix what you think is wrong and certainly do not make any cuts. Do not make those cuts. Simply keep your promise. It is all right, Senator Patterson, I'll be gone when you make your remarks but I'll listen contentedly from down the road, or maybe I'll read it next week. As Mr Howard said—Senator Teague quoted him so nicely—when asked about whether he should deal with the budget or keep his promises, `Our preference is to keep our promises.' That is all you have to do. All the minister has to do now is to come out and say, `Right. I've got the message. It is not the right thing to do for us to be looking at cuts in education, creating chaos in our universities and uniting vice‐chancellors, staff and students as they have not been united or politicised in many years.'

We have actually had such a change, and why? Because this minister went out with cavalier disregard for consequences and started the hares running herself. And the interesting question is this: what is the point of all this furore and chaos? Is it possible that the minister has just done this to distract people in some way, so that we are all going to be terribly busy rushing around having public campaigns, launching all sorts of programs, appeals, meetings and goodness knows what, but there will really not be any cuts at all? No‐one in their right mind could expect that the minister would make those remarks off the cuff, set all this chaos happening and then say, `Oh, well, we thought about it and there were not going to be any cuts anyhow. What we will do is just keep to our promise: no cuts.'

It could be, indeed, that this minister has betrayed such a level of skill—heavy irony here—and such a level of incompetent management that she may be causing this amount of chaos just for the fun of it, but I do not believe so. I believe Senator Vanstone has a very clear game plan, and that is that she has to deal with the absolute embarrassment she finds herself in of having to find cuts in the face of an absolute promise that there would be none. That is her problem. That is one of the problems she really has got. Say what you like about why this has got to be the case, but Mr Howard said that, out of cutting to reduce the deficit and keeping promises, his preference would be for keeping the promises. Well, Mr Howard, act on your preference.
If you are truthful about the budget deficit figures, you will know there is no black hole. You will know that, and that within a year or so all would come right. Those programs were well in train—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha.

—No, no! You go and read those figures of the forward estimates for a year or two under the Labor government's last budget, and you will find that there is no need to be in this kind of panic. The reason the government is in this kind of panic is that it has to have a fall‐back position in case Telstra is not sold. Certainly, any money from Telstra's sale will not be forthcoming for this budget.

BREAK.PARA: But, importantly, you made promises—heroic, huge promises—and you got your fundings wrong. Even in the estimate of savings from extending the waiting period from six months to two years for newly arrived Australians to be eligible for benefits in this country, you got those figures wrong by nearly $300 million. They are your own costings now. You estimated $600 million plus, and the figure came in at around $250 million or $280 million, as I remember. Then you added a few extra bits and pieces in—not the promise of not changing anything except the six months to two years—and you have thrown in some more benefits that people will not be eligible for. All that has done is get the figure up to $350 million.

You have got your own near-$300 million hole on wild promises. `We'll buy our way across the election barrier'. Well, you are over there. You would be much better off, as Senator Teague said, telling the truth. You would be much better off in education if you put out the bushfire as quickly as you could and got down to doing the sorts of things in education that you should.

I again quote Senator Abetz's great contribution. `One of the things that we have got to have,' he said, `is a vision. A vision is important and that is a challenge for Minister Vanstone.' We have been saying all along that the minister does not have a vision, but I did not think Senator Abetz would say it for us, too. `One of the things the minister has to get is a vision'—spot on, Senator.

She has not got a vision; she has got a policy vacuum and into that vacuum she sails and says, `Cuts, cuts.' Boom! Can she give us a clue? In what direction, Minister? Would you like us to cut anything in particular? `No'—boom!—`Cut the lot'. It really is an extraordinary thing. There is no policy. There is no program. There is no clear outline. There is no discussion paper. There is no sense of where people might be led by the minister to see more efficient, different or alternate ways of doing education. There is none of that; just—boom!—cuts.

I think the chaos is very properly sheeted home to the minister in this motion, in all the contributions from this side and, indeed, from Senator Teague. Do not get distracted by Senator Abetz's contribution. He is way off the mark.

There are a few points that I would like to highlight about why you should not proceed with these cuts. There is a very important reference on the front page of last Saturday's business section of the Age. Unfortunately, I do not have the quote here. It was written by an American adviser, whose name I do not dare hazard a guess at. He is an adviser to the United States government. He was urging countries like Australia to seriously consider not rushing to make savage reductions in deficits or to cut public expenditure because mostly the cuts fell in the very areas that were needed to promote growth, development, recovery and expansion of the economy.

The last thing you would want to be doing is cutting education. It is the very last place you should be cutting, because you would be stopping Australia's young—and now many older people with different qualifications, different talents and different capacities—from going into the marketplace and into the world and providing that wealth, that support, that development and all the sorts of things that are going to increase the productivity of the nation. It is quite daft to be cutting that area. It should be, as Senator Teague said, one area that has a very strong wall around it.

Senator Abetz might want to say what he likes about the Labor government—and I do not think any government is exempt from criticism—but I remind him that the Labor government dramatically increased expenditure in education. It nearly doubled it over its time in office. It certainly saw the Commonwealth funded places double to over 454,000, I think, and there are 650,000 students now in tertiary education in this country. That is a huge increase on what it was when we came into office in 1983.

I urge Senator Abetz to look at what the Malcolm Fraser government did to education funding when it was in office between 1975 and 1983. We feel so passionately about cuts in the tertiary sector because we have fought and struggled to get that education system up and running. That is another dimension of why it would be so bad to have the cuts proposed by Senator Vanstone.

It is so easy and quick to stop the machinery of the tertiary sector and so difficult to set it moving again that you cannot dare to cut away these dollars without appreciating that it is not all `Oh, well, we'll crank it up next year': you will not. If you wind that machinery back overnight, it will take five years, if not longer, to get it even back to where it was before the cuts.

Even crazier though, the vice-chancellors tell me that, if the minister's cuts go ahead as proposed, there will be in the short term a dramatic increase in outlays. The idea of postulating cuts that are going to cost you more has to be one of the most remarkable proposals that this new government has come up with.

It is also critical to note that, as well as winding back that machinery of tertiary sector education—knowing how long the lead time will be to get it going and knowing how important it is to the ongoing development and expansion of the economy, let alone the minds and hearts of the men and women who are in this country—cutting universities will have a savage effect on local and regional economies.

Those regional economies need not be put down to the University of Western Sydney at Penrith, Kingston, the Northern Territory, Lismore or Tasmania; those regions can be put down to something as significant as a state. Let me read what the Minister for Education in South Australia, Dr Such—not a Labor minister, but a member of the Liberal government in South Australia—had to say in last Saturday's edition of the Adelaide Advertiser:

The universities contribute $555 million to the South Australian economy and employ 6,500 people and are key contributors to the state's economic, intellectual, social and cultural life . . . Drastic cuts would have a severe impact on teaching and research programs and affect our pursuit of academic excellence, economic growth and development.

And so it would. Dr Such has been one of the most passionate people appealing to his state colleague Minister Vanstone, saying, `Please don't make these cuts.' In South Australia the economy is probably more sluggish than most other places across the country. For whatever reason—I have a lot of reasons why, but I will resist the temptation of mentioning them—it is still an area in which you would not want to do anything to create more risk or more hazard in that economy.

If you took $20 million or $30 million out of the South Australian economy—which is what the cuts proposed would mean for South Australia—the impact would be dramatic. No, you do not just send three professors home from university. No, you do not just stop some x-thousand students being unable to get there. You also stop a whole lot of businesses bang in their tracks, because those dollars are not being spent in those businesses anymore.

Housing will slacken. Mortgages will not be able to be paid. It has a very significant effect on the local economy. If you are not sure about that, look at what has happened to Canberra since the announcement of the Public Service cuts in this town. You all know that it is true. You must talk to Comcar drivers, as I do. Many of them run businesses in this town—not just building, buying and selling houses but secondary businesses. They will all tell you what has happened to the economy in Canberra—and that is not saying anything about housing prices. That can happen in South Australia, too. Dr Such knows it and he is desperate for it not to happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —You know all about it after the State Bank. You know all about it after John Bannon.

—It took you a long time, senator. It is not the only reason. You have been there for a very long time. Madam Acting Deputy President, a minute ago I was chided because I did not direct my remarks through the chair. I would like you to suggest, if Senator Campbell gets carried away again, that he should also direct his remarks through the chair.

BREAK.PARA: The other important point about the impact of the tertiary sector on the regional economy is the very large and growing expenditure into research. One of the best things South Australia does, better than anywhere else in Australia, is grow wine. It produces something like 60 per cent of Australia's wine. Of course, amongst that is the best of Australia's wine. The very best wines come from South Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, Senator Crowley. I have to interject on that.

—You can ring the world. Grange Hermitage, from South Australia, has just won the world prize for the very best wine. We produce absolutely brilliant wine. We produce at least 60 per cent of Australia's wine, maybe a bit more than that.

BREAK.PARA: This year the wine industry is thundering towards $500 million worth of exports. That industry has grown from almost zero exports a few years ago to this dramatic increase. That has been largely because of the enterprise in that industry, which has been supported and encouraged by export development program grants and all those sorts of things that the Labor government did on behalf of that wine industry. It is also assisted by the splendid research done through the University of Adelaide, at the Waite Institute, and through the wine and brandy institute.

These are the bits and pieces of the equation that must be taken into account if we are talking about the impact of cuts in our tertiary sector. We need to talk about the impact of cutting back research dollars. There is not only an impact on the people who are doing the research—the loss of young researchers and the possible brain drain—but also the very immediate effect of the loss of that research on our industry, our productivity, our manufacturing and our exports. I mention the wine industry because it is such a very good example in South Australia; but there are any number of those examples across the country.

The other thing the Labor government did was to establish cooperative research centres. There are a number of them around the country. Again, these are the very best associations, or they are very good associations—perhaps there is always room for the better to be the best. These cooperative research centres are a splendid coming together of industry and tertiary sector university to promote research and to apply that research in Australia's manufacturing and scientific endeavour.

I am absolutely sure the government supports those ventures and would not like to see anything cutting them back. But you cannot talk about benefits to the economy and try to make sure that the economy is in the very best situation and then take decisions that are immediately and dramatically, with a multiplier effect, going to cut back the economy of this country. It is for those reasons—let alone the fact that one of the very best investments we can make in the future generation is to make sure our children have the opportunity of a tertiary education, if that is what they choose, and to make sure that more and more of them have that opportunity, because of the increased number of places—that we should look at the so-called multiplier effect on development, investment, research, industry and export if we cut back in the areas of research and university investment.

I would also like to make clear the impact of cuts on two or three sectors that grew dramatically under a Labor government. I would hate to see any cutback in those sectors. Some 20 or so years ago, if you finished your schooling and left, that was about it for your education for the rest of your life. You had very little opportunity to get back into the education system. Over the last 13 years of Labor government there has been a very significant and intentional change so that people do have the opportunity for education, including tertiary education, over fairly much the whole of their life.

Tertiary education for mature age students has been not only personally very satisfying for those people but also of tremendous contribution and importance to this community. I read in the paper yesterday or the day before that an Aboriginal man in South Australia has graduated as a doctor. I think he is in his 50s. He has had a life of any number of things, but he was not presented with the opportunity of an education when he was a much younger person. Under the Labor government's program there was much more flexibility for people in and out of education over the whole of their lives. That is one important area.

Another very big and very significant area of growth was the special programs for disadvantaged people, particularly people with a disability. There was much better access. For people from non-English speaking backgrounds there was the importance of assistance in English as a second language, certainly as it was the language of their studies in many cases. Also terribly important was the dramatic increase in the number of women who had the opportunity for the first time to get into tertiary institutions.

I still find it very poignant meeting families who say that a family member—an aunt, an uncle, a daughter or a niece—is the first in their family to have the opportunity of getting a tertiary education. It is poignant because they are the first. It is dramatically exciting because they are the first and because they will not be the last.

We have seen hard‐won gains in education for our daughters as well as our sons. There are much better retention rates. The number of girls and boys completing year 12 has gone from 37 per cent to about 80 per cent. There has also been a very significant increase in the number of girls and women who are able to take up tertiary education—they now number over 50 per cent in our institutions. That is a significant increase compared with even the 1983 figure. I would hate to see any cuts in the tertiary sector, but I would also hate to see those gains lost. We know full well that the people who are always most likely to lose when there are cuts are those who are the poorest, those who are the most marginal, those who are the least able to argue their case.

This motion deserves our strongest support. The minister's behaviour in relation to the tertiary sector deserves our strongest condemnation. Not only has there been chaos but reputations could well be in jeopardy. University research is certainly jeopardised. The quality of service for students is jeopardised. Teaching numbers and morale will be hit for six.

It is well and good for senators opposite—I preclude Senator Teague from this—to say that all those are just promises. This is a huge amount of chaos for something that may not happen. It clearly indicates that something will happen. It will quite clearly be damaging, difficult and destructive for our tertiary sector and, in every way you look at it, a negative for this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran, Sen Julian

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to contribute to this wide ranging debate in which Senator Crowley took the opportunity to talk about the South Australian wine industry. Congratulations on parts of your speech, Senator Crowley. In certain parts of it you showed great passion, which makes me think that opposition suits you well. You never showed the same passion and care for administration when you were on this side of the house and you were in charge of your own portfolio. As I say, being in opposition suits you well. It is where your passion is best brought out.

SPEECH.PARA: Not unexpectedly the speakers from the other side of the house have used this motion to simply sink the debate to its base level of politics and to launch an attack on ministers. When people from the education sector read the Hansard they will no doubt see that very little real, constructive contribution has come from the other side. Those on the other side have continually denied the economic imperatives this government now faces and have thrown in platitudes about the worth of education, which of course we all agree with and support. It is unlikely that the mover of this motion and the many people who have spoken about it will get any thanks from vice‐chancellors for simply crowding the issue and taking base political opportunities.

I know members of the Labor Party love to join a demonstration. If they see a banner, they will join it. Only yesterday they were in full support of the building workers' demonstration, let alone today's demonstrations, and supported their tax rorts. If they see a banner up a street, they will get right behind it. It is one of the Labor Party's great traditions and loves.

There are times when demonstrations are worth joining, but I cannot accept that the vice-chancellors and the demonstrators, the students, really believe they will get any comfort from or owe any sort of debt to members of the other side of the house for their administration of the education portfolio. In every budget they brought down in their long 13 years in office funding per student fell. The evidence of that has been borne out by the fact that the student‐staff ratio some 13 year ago was around 10 students to one staffer. That ratio has climbed to 18 students to one staffer. So the ratio nearly doubled during the previous government's term.

Further, without doubt the greatest losers in this area have been regional universities. That of course is my primary interest. There was no equity in funding for universities. The regional universities were the ones that lost out. For example, funding for students of city universities like Melbourne University has been higher than that for those attending regional universities such as Ballarat University. There never was any equity in the previous government's funding. The losers were always the regional universities. Ballarat University are still waiting for funding committed by the previous government for their establishment as a university. They are yet to receive that. Regional universities which were created during the previous government's term were never backed up with the funding necessary to carry out their duties at the level that is expected of a university.

I also mention the equality assurance mechanism—another scheme the previous government introduced. I cannot believe the vice‐chancellors think they can gain comfort from support from the previous government, now the opposition. They should cast their minds back to that scheme, whereby universities were ranked and placed in bands. They were ranked in bands of one to six. Of course, those ranked in the bottom bands—that is, those ranked five or six—were all regional universities.

The criteria were very shonky. All the regional universities ended up at the bottom of the ranking. The inequity of this criteria, which have since been abandoned, was shown in the case of Newcastle University. It has one of Australia's best medical schools and it has a high rating engineering school. Yet it was No. 5 in the rankings. So when it publicised itself overseas to try to attract students to its medical school, the first question asked was: where are you on the government's rankings? Newcastle University had to say, `We're down near the bottom.'

That was the sort of disadvantage placed on regional universities. So the rich got richer and the poor got poorer in the education portfolio. As I said, that scheme has since been abandoned. I ask the vice‐chancellors to cast their minds back to when that scheme was established and how poor and wacky the criteria really were. They should not place themselves in the hands of the opposition when they make their approaches to this government, because the truth is that much of the heat in this debate has dissipated, has died down, even before the demonstrations started today.

The vice‐chancellors have sought a meeting with the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). That meeting will take place in the next week or so. The Australian Vice‐Chancellors Committee now says it is ready to work cooperatively with the government. Perhaps on those two points they have cast their minds back to the record of the previous government and they know only too well that they should not side with the opposition or take any comfort from this motion by the opposition. They know the record only too well.

In order to reassure the education sector—the vice‐chancellors, the staff and the students—I wish to paraphrase the words of the Prime Minister. I am sure he will reassure the vice‐chancellors when they meet with him in a week or two. The Prime Minister reconfirmed only last week that the coalition's policies will be upheld. He is patently aware that governments must return to upholding their commitments, if for no other reason than the great cynicism that the Australian public have towards politicians and parliaments which was set rock hard after the 1993 election when the Labor government broke their promises wholesale and increased taxes wholesale. The Prime Minister said that the forthcoming budget will show only too well our commitment to our belief in upholding the thrust of our policies.

It should be noted that the coalition did signal some changes in education, if people care to read a little more closely—particularly Senator Crowley—our policy document. Some changes were signalled and there will be some restructuring within the education department, such as the winding up of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training. The enormous task of bringing down the budget in surplus is the No. 1 strategy of the government—due, of course, to the legacy left to us by the previous government.

The education sector, along with all sectors, must meet new efficiency levels. I noticed only yesterday in the higher education section of the Australian newspaper—a well‐ respected and well‐read section of the newspaper—in their regular column `Your say' they posed a question to the sector: could your colleagues be more efficient in their work? I do not hold this up as the definitive poll of the education sector, but it is interesting and it is a guide towards efficiency. In reply to that question, 60 per cent answered yes. As I say, I do not hold that up as the most definitive poll of the education sector but obviously that is a fair indication that there are efficiencies to be made in that sector.

It should not be lost on those involved in the education sector that we do have a policy, a primary commitment, a promise that we have made to the Australian people for fiscal responsibility, which does translate into a balanced budget. While I do not seek to get bogged down in the broader economic arguments, frankly, the vice‐chancellors should realise that that is the angst in the community at the moment. We want to sheet home the broader economic situation that we are faced with. I hope some time will be left for Senator Campbell to pick up on that point.

The vice‐chancellors should also realise that the reward for bringing the budget into surplus—unless no vice‐chancellor or student has a mortgage or a credit card—is downward pressure on interest rates. So our priority commitment to all Australians is for a balanced budget or a budget in surplus.

Nevertheless, the foundation stones for our higher education policy remain in place. Our policy shows that the coalition understands the work and are committed to the support of high‐quality universities for the intellectual, cultural, economic and social benefit of the nation. For all those reasons, the truth probably is that both sides of the parliament believe in the priority commitment to higher education.

Regardless of how we pull and tug on this issue, although it could be much better, Australia does have one of the best university infrastructures, if not in the world, at least within Asia. That is something we can be proud of. That has been built up over 50 years. As a National Party member, the area that is of most concern to me is student access to higher education. The coalition policy gives great assurances regarding student access. It is one of its three major goals. I place it as my No. 1 goal. Following on from access to education comes equality and choice.

For the rural and regional population, the question of access is supported, firstly, by Austudy and, equally important, its regional universities. At the risk of stating the obvious, it is worthy to note that the rural community holds education for its children as the single most important issue. There was great evidence of this during the drought—and I do not doubt that in many parts of the eastern board of Australia the drought is still at its height. During the height of the drought some 18 months ago, farming families in all their troubles saw their priority as maintaining their children's education through access to Austudy, which, under the then rules, was being denied to so many drought stricken farmers.

The coalition believes that Austudy is one of the most important tools for accessing education. Yet we have been left with a system that has become complicated and is not meeting its original, worthy goals. This stems from the introduction by the previous government of the actual means test, which has led to an administrative nightmare. Unfortunately, this government is left with the actual means test that we did not design and that has caused a logjam of some 3,000 unprocessed applications for Austudy, and yet the academic year has already started.

In relation to regional universities, I am sure Senator Vanstone will not mind my mentioning that the National Party MPs have stoutly presented a very worthy case for their funding. Probably more than city based universities, regional universities link closely with the community. While so many people have been claiming today—from the Democrats to the ALP—that they have been seeing vice‐chancellors and others in the education system, I can fortuitously and perhaps even coincidentally say that I have met representatives from the Bendigo district. I would like to take time out to wax lyrical about the Bendigo campus because it is a case in point.

There are university representatives on the board of Bendigo Art Gallery and the science museum, which shows the close links to the community. Moreover, the local council in conjunction with the university will be building a very high quality athletics track for both public and university use. The same university, Bendigo University, is undertaking a study on the impact of gaming machines on the local economy. Such are the many uses of regional universities.

The Bendigo University feeds other major centres, such as the Mildura and Shepparton area where courses are undertaken under the stewardship of the Bendigo University. In all, the Bendigo University campus directly and indirectly contributes some $100 million per annum to the local economy and, just as importantly, if not more importantly, it employs over 430 staff.

Having stated the importance of the regional campuses, I say for the information of the opposition that no regional campus will be forced to close. To the contrary: this is nothing short of a scare campaign. Senator Vanstone has been very supportive and understanding in regard to the importance of regional universities. I quote verbatim from a press statement she issued on 22 May, which states:
. . . Senator Vanstone . . . today reaffirmed the Coalition's recognition of the importance of regional universities.
Senator Vanstone said speculation that regional universities were under threat was nothing more than an attempt by the Labor Party to create an atmosphere of panic in regional areas.

"The Coalition recognises the important contribution regional Australia makes to the nation and understands the individual needs of people who live outside the metropolitan cities," Senator Vanstone said.

In conclusion, I am very confident that the opportunism of this particular motion will be seen for what it is out in the education sector: base, political opportunism and an attack against a good minister.
